headline: No reward for loyalty.
pros: The company values diversity and is an equal opportunity employer. Well organized, things like pay, time work are done in an orderly manner. Conveniently located within the Dallas area, with great access to major freeways in the area.
cons: Seem to prefer outsiders than to promoting staff who have been there for years. Pay increases once a year but very minimal at best. They use a percentage system but the problems is the cost of living in Dallas has far exceeded what many employees are stuck with.

headline: Not bad place to work
pros: Great benefits and investment opportunities
cons: Some people are very stuck in there ways and only watch out for there buddies instead of the whole team

headline: Good place to work
pros: Good people that seem to care about their workers.  There's a fair amount of turnover so it may take a while to feel like you're part of the team, but when you settle down, they seem to value your inputs and work/life balance.  Benefits are good and salary is good.
cons: The work can be hard.  The benefits are still pretty good, but they are not as good as in years past. There isn't really a credit union on campus anymore and the fitness center isn't as nice as it used to be.

headline: Laid off by TI
pros: Enjoyed working there, good relationship with other employees
cons:
Management decided to cut costs and arbitrarily laid off a lot of their top employees.
In same week, I got a raise, bonus, re-elected to the techstaff and laid off.

headline: "Good enough"
pros: work life balance, good amount of time off, stable
cons: not enough software folks, often slow-moving

headline: Supply Chain Global Purchasing
pros: The people are great resources.
cons: Pay is fair but could be better.

headline: Good place to learn if you have passion for Semiconductor industry
pros: They have many events for employee motivation,
cons: The latest change in top management makes it difficult to employees voice heard by management. Too many gating process.

headline: product engineer
pros: bonus, profit sharing, widen knowledge and experiences ......................
cons: workload imbalance.... . . . .

headline: Good opportunities for early career
pros: Great rotation, training programs for new hires. Many opportunities to meet upper management. Good work environment and culture.  I appreciate the support / highlighting of off-hours work using company products (i.e. "DIY with TI day").
cons: Training and approval for conference attendance has dropped off in the last 10 years. Company is less focused on experienced engineers.

headline: Engineering supervisor
pros: Profit Sharing, environment, and stablility
cons: Very polictical and promotions do not go to individuals who actually rate them.

headline: Access Rotational Program
pros: Allows you the ability to explore different career options compared to what you studied. Almost like an applied MBA program.
cons: Hard to decide what you want to do and focus specifically in that area. Otherwise its a very good opportunity.

headline: Marketing  Manager
pros: Excellent  work environment and lot of flexibility to move based on career interests. Provides  good  visibility  to upper management  and leadership.
cons: None. Since quality is considered  a key care about, at times the time to readiness  may appear longer. I view this as a positive since these checks and balances are in place.

headline: Decent place to work but nothing flashy
pros:
-Stable and good work life balance unless working in an Apple focused group 
-Dallas is way cheaper than most tech hubs
-Very good bonuses when the company does well.  Last 3 have be ~15-17% of your annual salary
-Lots of room to grow your skills through training or seminars
-Market leader in analog parts so future is bright if that's your field of semiconductors
-Very nice (but older) people
cons:
-Yearly raises are minimal in the 2% range even for pay grade bumps
-Work can be slow sometimes
-Salary and benefits are lower than what you'd get in a more competitive tech hub like Austin or SI Valley
-The culture is stuffy compared to the hipper silicon valley companies (no shorts, no parties, no free food/drinks/snacks)

headline: Great company, enjoying the benefits, but not current job
pros:
- Employee-focused company
- Profit Sharing
- Great people to work with, many being employed at the company for 15+ years
- Lots of freedom to move around horizontally
- Excellent training provided to grow knowledge and skills
cons:
- Difficult to move up the chain because not a lot of roles between lowest employee and CEO, and employees tend to stay long time so they occupy management positions longer
- Since employees tend to stay longer and people are well connected, difficult to shake off bad reputation if you are viewed negatively by upper management
- Employees are secretly ranked and the how behind the ranking is not shared
- Lower salaries and raises compared to other companies
- Not a great work-life balance available

headline: Digital Design Engineer
pros: Get to work on different things
cons: Lot of responsibilities once you start performing well

headline: Director of Marketing
pros: Good financial behavior, good TSA program
cons: New development cycles are long

headline: TI Engineering
pros: Great compensation and benefit packages
cons: The large business culture stifles creativity

headline: Analog Design Intern
pros:
Friendly Environment 
People are willing to help with the questions you have
Good pay
cons: There was nothing I didn't like

headline: Tsa
pros: Everyone is extremely helpful. There is always someone willing to take the extra time to help you get up to pace
cons: Very competitive work environment. Always have to be on your toes

headline: Good place to work
pros:
Good environment
Good work culture
Better work life balance
Work from home during emergency
cons:
Access to internal JOS
Role specific training programs

headline: Great Company
pros: The culture at TI is awesome. The environment is laid back and the people you get to work with are always willing to help out when needed. The benefits package is also great. Strongly encouraged to move laterally or horizontally within the company depending on your preference. Work flexibility and ability to maintain work/life balance are very appealing.
cons: From a technology standpoint as a software engineer, you won't be working on anything considered 'cutting-edge'. The work is very interesting and challenging but the software used to do it isn't the latest and greatest.

headline: Freelance ghostwriter
pros: Very professional organization. Project descriptions were clear.
cons: No cons. Very easy to work with

headline: Good company overall
pros: Good benefits, good pay, get to meet a lot of brilliant people.
cons: It is very difficult to move from group to group if you are interested in a different role.

headline: Engineering Manager
pros: Good company. Very profit oriented.
cons: Management tends to make hasty decisions

headline: Fine Company
pros: Company has many different groups for career changes, great pay and benefits, global company great from business side and interactions. Tech company fast pace, go go  go very exciting. Work in a wide variety of products and industries. See and learn lots of great new technologies. Very supportive of females and minorities in all levels of the company.
cons: You will work many hours. Always seems there is something more that needs to be done. Plus global means most our your nights will be conference calls.

headline: Solid Semiconducor Company
pros: Good stable company to work for.
cons: Not a lot of effort put into to maintaining employees.

headline: Very good place to work for.
pros: One of the best company in DFW area which recognizes engineering talent.
cons: Hiring process can be better.

headline: great company
pros: Great colleagues, technology. I loved everything about working in that company.
cons: I really can't think about anything bad. Maybe organize more events in the company.

headline: Great People and Great Benefits
pros: Trusted you to do your job. Great people. Good benefits. Very interesting work.
cons: Hours are pretty tough, especially if you work nights. 12 hour shifts, 3 to 4 days a weeks with a floating Wednesday or Saturday.

headline: Great place to work!
pros:
Work life balance
Great learning experience
Compensation is good
cons: Cannot think of anything bad

headline: Overall steady job
pros: Plenty of interesting challenges and priority to having appropriate work-life balance. Profit sharing bonus has been great past few years. Managers do care and try to help you develop in your role.
cons: Many positions are understaffed so there is risk of being overworked. Pay is fair but not quite a plus outside the heavily taxed bonus.

headline: Good work life balance
pros:
1. Leaders with strong technical background and always accessible
2. Good opportunity for learning new  things through various trainings
3. Open culture
cons: Nothing specific about cons ...

headline: Great company, but be politically savvy
pros: Great benefits. Room for lateral movement
cons: Lots of talk about diversity, but in practice, it varies by team. So, do your homework and watch for politics

headline: Communications
pros: Ethical company with smart people that provides challenging work. There are many opportunities to find a good career path insise the company and get involved in community.
cons: Working at any big company often has many layers of approval before able to move forward. Gaining alignment with the right level of management is important.

headline: Ethical Company
pros:
You can develop your professionalism and communication because of regular interaction with stakeholders worldwide
Work-life balance. The company has recreational facilities - basketball court, fitness gym, etc that you can use during your break time or outside your shift
Generally, friendly and humble people in the workplace
Benefits - profit share, rice allowance, medical, insurance, dental, etc
cons:
Politics everywhere
Below average compensation (provincial rate)
Late night meetings if your counterparts / stakeholders are onshore

headline: Specialist
pros: Open and innovative. Great training and experiences for new college graduates.
cons: No real cons, can sometimes be a little difficult to navigate but everyone is willing to help you.

headline: Time to change the high level leaders
pros:
has a variety of product lines.
great colleagues.
cons:
conflicts between product lines and sales department.
finance-oriented.
no new, shining technology for a long time. less competitive capability

headline: Production Supervisor
pros: Wonderful environment to grow and learn
cons:
Not enough advancement for operators.
Anything above operator requires degree

headline: Key Account Manager(Snr Technical Sales Engineer)
pros: Great place to start your career, excellent global exposure
cons: Politics in some teams, inefficient data capture systems which require a lot of manual effort for Sales teams

headline: Very stable, but very bland
pros: TI hires straight from college for a very generous salary, and the atmosphere promotes a lot of learning early on. As a way to get a well known, reputable company on your resume TI is amazing! The job pays well, has great benefits, and is very stable.
cons: Worker morale seems to be a step above pure apathy outside of management. The environment tailors itself as a treadmill, an endless pursuit, rather than having clear cut goals. There also does not seem to be a feeling of upward momentum. It seems stability has come at the cost of striving for something greater.

headline: Financial Analyst
pros: Good large company benefits; pros depend greatly on which department you are in;
cons: Cons depend on department you are in.

headline: Accounting Clerk
pros: Texas instruments have a great working environment because of the place and the people around and it a very good place to start your professional  career..
cons: i think i dont have anything to say with these..

headline: Test Engineer
pros: Good to start a career!!!  Good Company!
cons: None that i can think of

headline: Work satisfaction on downwards trajectory
pros:
Commitment to ethics
Majority of people are great to work with
Benefits are decent
cons:
Can be very political
Dallas is the center of the universe
A few appallingly bad middle-level managers poison the waters for others
Increasing bureaucracy affecting productivity and enjoyment of work
Over time, policies tend to drift from one extreme to the other (for example, from too little structure and reporting some years ago to a stifling amount today or from growth focus to margin focus), rarely stabilizing at a reasonable level
Way too many "managers" who only manage without adding value
Lots of lip-service to innovation, but little understanding of what actually promotes innovation

headline: Equipment Engineer
pros: Great pay and potential to move from one roll to another.  Benefits are very competitive and there are a lot of after work activities available to become involved in.  Work is challenging and allows for a fair amount of autonomy.
cons: While there is some amount of autonomy, management will place a lot of extra responsibilities on individuals outside of their primary roles.  This can causes many individuals to feel either overwhelmed or that they cannot focus on the primary goals of their job.  Work can become monotonous depending on your roll.  Additionally, management is constantly trying to reduce the number of personnel in manufacturing while the workload is not decreasing.

headline: TI Marketing
pros: Very large sales force overwhelms competition
cons:
Too much time spent  with internal reporting, cya and  navigating sloppy systems. Too little time  available for customer focused activity.
Prefers  fresh college hires- not a good environment for  people over 45

headline: Business Planner
pros: Great company with good work ethics, team oriented, good benefits, recognizable, good reputation. Company offers interesting projects and career opportunities.
cons: Large company with aggressive goals, not enough work/life balance. HQ location is not in a so desirable neighborhood.

headline: My opinion of TI
pros: Great company to work for.
cons: None to mention, I was very happy at TI

headline: Great upper management. Good work balance.
pros: Upper management knows what they are doing guiding the company. Flexible policies so easy to balance family life.
cons: Headquarters in an iffy neighborhood. Typical layoff cycles but worse as company is in Dallas with less hi-tech competitors. So annual reviews feels less competitive.

headline: Verification
pros: Smart people to work with. Has wide variety of devices,which gives flexibility to move internally and grow your skillset. Great profit sharing.
cons:
Very slow employee growth.
Only stable semiconductor company at this location and know it pretty well.

headline: Big Company
pros: If you an the type of person who wants a steady job with and want to progress in your career as a manager this is a great place.
cons: If you want to grow as an individual contributor look elsewhere.

headline: Design Engineer
pros: Good work life balance, good profit sharing, engineers in the group are very smart, good 401K matching, good time bank for vacation
cons: Management is not very efficient, a lot of meetings, office political in high levels, health insurance is not very good,

headline: Design Engineer
pros: Good work life balance, good profit sharing, engineers in the group are very smart, good 401K matching, good time bank for vacation
cons: Management is not very efficient, a lot of meetings, office political in high levels, health insurance is not very good,

headline: Good company
pros: Lots of opportunities for diverse experiences
cons: Must be in Dallas to effectively contribute

headline: Engineer
pros:
- Good benefits
- Complex work allows complex thinking
cons:
- Lack of work life balance
- Micro-management by middle managers

headline: Great Company
pros: Pragramatic in term of business. Take good care of the people
cons: Left France after so many years of presence...should have tried harder to stay

headline: Stable company
pros: Good learning environment, excellent technical resources. Good compensation and opportunities
cons: Lots of pressure depending on group and managers can be a pain to work with due to lack of experience.

headline: Expert Advisor
pros: Got to do some amazing stuff and learn new stuff even before it was release to the market.
cons: This job doesn't pay as its just online reviewing not location based work.

headline: Fellow, Technical Manager
pros: Good technical people and some interesting projects
cons: Very poor management. - fear of risk to many politics

headline: Great co workers and great mentor
pros:
Great training program that lasts about one month, including technical training and project management. 
Co workers are very nice. Team building every month.
cons: Expect for that I have to pay for my housing. But it is worthwhile the learning opportunity and build your network in the indistry.

headline: Sales
pros: Good sales new revenue and business tracking tools. Good product technical sales application for customer applications discovery and product selection.
cons: Internal priority on new college hires.

headline: One of the best SC companies to work for
pros:
- Long Term Strategy and Vision 
- Opportunity to work on next big technology
- Great diversity in the company
- Flexibility to try out different roles 
- Diversity across markets and device portfolio
- Highly ethical company
cons:
- Having a top down approach 
- Size of the company can inhibit speed with one can innovate/ bring change

Nothing else apart from these stand out as cons

headline: TI general
pros: Opportunity to move up ladder
cons: Management is mostly pulled from sales with little development experience. Adds to some bureaucracy

headline: High Expectations, but High Rewards as Well
pros:
Profit sharing.
Excellent compensation.
World wide company.
Excellent health care with the high deductible plan coupled with an HSA.
Small company feel with big company support.
cons: Work culture has a tendency to encourage workaholics. The CEO expects the individual employee to speak up and be in charge of their own work life balance, so if you do not have a strong voice, your team might have the tendency to way overwork you.

headline: Application Engineer
pros: TI was a great company to work for. Its pay and bonus were based on your performance, nothing else.  Top performers were well rewarded.
cons: Most of the management was not technically oriented. So it was not innovative eccentric. It was purely sales driven. In long run, it could hurt its competitiveness in the market.

headline: Good place if you want to be a passive cog in the machinery. Expect resistance if you want to be a driver cog.
pros:
Incredible and motivated bunch of co-workers
Good amenities on campus.
Some projects and technology you get to work on can be quite fascinating
cons:
Pay can be a tad to significantly lower than software development jobs
Engineers are relegated to being cogs in the machinery, seldom allowed a high level view of the project.
Management thinks they know what's best. Don't leverage the wisdom of the incredibly smart people they've got working there.

headline: One of the better semiconductor companies
pros: Salary is very competitive compared to other semiconductor companies, especially considering Texas cost of living.  The company is doing well and has a good strategy, for at least the short term.  There are a lot of smart people working at the company.
cons: It can be hard to move between groups.  There are frequent layoffs.  The product development tends to be rather slow and cautious.

headline: Good company.
pros: Good company to work for. Good bonus every year.
cons: Lot of restructuring and job losses.

headline: Great Company to work
pros: Lot of great resources and opportunity to grow in many ways.
cons: While it's great to nurture young leaders, there are definitely some arrogant, immature and insecure young managers promoted through the combination of their own merits and the management favoritism.

headline: TI is NOT the company it once was
pros: Very talented technical work force, above average salaries & benefits, good stock performance despite waning innovation and differentiation across many product groups
cons: TI's reputation as one of the best semiconductor companies and one of the best places to work has declined significantly over the past decade.  TI is an old-style company with antiquated management practices, rampant ageism, and a leadership team that preaches the company name alone sells products.  From the top down, there is a solitary focus on sales and, by and large, innovation is discouraged.

headline: Product engineering
pros: Great size company with mature system and working culture
cons: Responsibilities focused on specific area

headline: Highest pay for entry level, easy work
pros:
Good hours: 4 days on 3 days off then 3 days on 4 days off, 12 hour shifts
Awesome pay: overtime pay every day after 8 hours, highest pay for entry level work
Profit sharing: you get a percentage of your pay as a bonus every February
Easy work: the actual work is usually automated 

I was a manufacturing specialist for 10 years then left to try an accounting job. Ended up hating office work and have returned to TI. Best company to work for once you become a TIer.
cons: The specialists have to start as contractors and it can take anywhere from 1-4 years to become permanent. Changing shifts or fabs is almost impossible.

headline: Digital Desgin
pros: Nice working environment, friendly colleagues, and many company activities.
cons: The salary is around average.

headline: Field Application Engineer
pros: Good working environment and lifestyle
cons: Low salaries and more paper work

headline: great company
pros:
big company 
great working environment
nice mentor
flexible working hour
good benefit
cons: nothing i can bring up

headline: Fair benefits
pros: Good benefits but quickly adapting to market benefits changes.  This has offset the balance between the lower salaries and the new benefits.  There appears to be a sincere and fair effort in approaching a good level of benefits given the market changes.
cons: Are not competitive with market salaries.

headline: Good work/life balance, too conversative
pros: Smart engineers, good work/life balance - people usually don't work late at night or on weekends.
cons: Conservative and slow to react to market changes. Decision making is tentative and usually delayed. Not a lot of room to advance because hardly anybody at TI leave for other jobs in the Dallas area. People often work here for life so there's not a lot of openings.

headline: Project Manager
pros: Good benefits and nice facilities.
cons: Antiquated systems and business processes and highly uncooperative people who lack greatly in communication skills.  The company reminds me of the movie "The Village" where people have been following a certain way so long but never realized corporate America had actually advanced quite a bit and they were left behind.

headline: Good Company. Avoid Marketing Department
pros: Big corporation with good benefits and okay perks.
cons: Not enough maternity leave. Marketing Department has gone downhill in the last ~3 years. Advancement is based on who you're friends with. There's no roadmap to advancement and no regard to actual work product; it's literally about how well you're liked or not.

headline: Texas Instruments
pros: Too big to fail, likely buying up smaller competitors
cons: Slow to innovate, prefers to buy innovators

headline: R&D spending keeps getting smaller
pros: Good work / life balance. Plenty of opportunity for advancement. Generally secure employment at the major sites. Diverse employee group.
cons: Remote design centers are becoming tough to survive. Few women in engineering roles; those with good skills can move swiftly in the managerial path.

headline: Challenging work team
pros: Good benefits package. One of the more stable semiconductor companies with good reputation. The company is quick to identify any losing business, so I would say good vision.
cons:
Deadlock and feeling stuck with the job and company due to the location. Dallas has no opportunity other than TI for semiconductors.
Company policies slightly on the conservative side with regards to flexible work schedule, maternity leave.
No sick leave given to employees, when you are sick the day off goes from your vacation days.

headline: Challenging work team
pros: Good benefits package. One of the more stable semiconductor companies with good reputation. The company is quick to identify any losing business, so I would say good vision.
cons:
Deadlock and feeling stuck with the job and company due to the location. Dallas has no opportunity other than TI for semiconductors.
Company policies slightly on the conservative side with regards to flexible work schedule, maternity leave.
No sick leave given to employees, when you are sick the day off goes from your vacation days.

headline: My TI Experience as a new college grad (TSA)
pros: The pay is really great and everyone that is in the program all seem to have the same personality which makes networking easy.
cons: Not knowing where you may possibly end up while doing the rotation?

headline: Depends what you value
pros: Good company with industry respect
cons: They work you hard, but pay better than average

headline: Office Manager
pros: Wonderful place to work.  I especially loved the profit sharing that TI does and the folks were great to work with.
cons: Wish they wouldn't have had to close their Austin office.

headline: Product Engineer
pros: TI provide a lot of training resource self-development. The benefit is descent. Working environment is nice.
cons: Working long hours due to tight schedule

headline: Great Company to Work
pros: Texas Instruments is wonderful company to work. The ethics and principles followed are the main area that I liked. Secondly, they take care of employee as a family of their own showing consistent growth for all potential employees. The culture is open and everyone is reachable at anytime. The synergy within the teams encourages you to go to office with great enthusiasm everyday.
cons: The company is aggressive in its targets and goals. So need to work hard to ensure you are inline with the achievements aimed.

headline: overall good company
pros:
good place for young people to grow with a broad variety of jobs.
decent compensation
responsible high level management
Friendly working environment
positive company image
cons: big and thus less innovative in a lot of sub-orgs

headline: Long-timer at TI
pros: TI has good work/life balance, decent benefits, and historical stability - basically, all the usual benefits of a large company.
cons: Base salary is not too competitive, retirement matching could be improved

headline: Excellent culture and good benefits
pros: Good matching on 401(k). Health benefits are pretty good - were better before.
cons: Buddy culture - latch on to someone who you think is going to go up the ladder and you can rise with them.

headline: Tesas Instruments: a view from an retiree
pros:
Strong IDM Iintegrated Device Manufacturer) in analog IC, power IC, and embedded ICs with
good market shares with highly structured organizations and strong leadership.
cons: Too many reorganizations with constantly changing and confusing landscape.  Too much emphasis on numbers and short-term planning. Communication and coordination among different groups can be difficult.

headline: Good, Intense
pros: Good work/life balance and decent benefits. 401k could use improvement. 50% matching up to limit would be better than dollar for dollar to 4% (current).
cons: Pressure to accomplish tasks can be high at points, but any engineering company will have the "need to deliver" at some point.

headline: Great!
pros: Great company to work for!
cons: None that I can think of

headline: Good for Honing Your Skills
pros:
Friendly  Work Environment
Lots of Trainings
cons:
Politics in Work
Management Changes Frequently

headline: Pretty good
pros: Good company good culture. Nice managers
cons: Too much travel. Pressure is big

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Great work culture, Excellent Pay
cons: Dont think of any particular cons

headline: Great!
pros: Great work environment..good work experience..project flexibility..technical training workshops
cons: Easy to land up into something uninteresting..low employee appreciation..very difficult to convert full time

headline: Intern Perspective
pros:
I really enjoyed my summer at TI and am looking forward to going back.
You get exposed to a variety of areas and there are many networking opportunities for interns.  I found the work both challenging and interesting, while help from peers and supervisors was encouraged across the board.
cons:
Location -- Texas is great, but for specific jobs it seems there are only a few places (mostly in Texas) you can work despite all the nationwide locations.
"Remote" Locations -- Interns not in Dallas get access to less networking events.

headline: senior engineer
pros: empoyee frindly benefits , good company to work
cons: Promotions dont get easily , difficult to see ourself getting promoted

headline: TI is good place but watch for politics
pros: The compensation is very good
cons: Office politics and lack of diversity

headline: Design Engineer
pros: CAD Design , Senior Design Engineer Technician 10 years: QC Reliability/PM Maintenance/LAB Test/Customer and Production interaction/Customer Analysis Report Findings
cons: Recertifying OHSA, USCG LIC. 50 TON 2016,

headline: Design Engineer
pros: CAD Design , Senior Design Engineer Technician 10 years: QC Reliability/PM Maintenance/LAB Test/Customer and Production interaction/Customer Analysis Report Findings
cons: Recertifying OHSA, USCG LIC. 50 TON 2016,

headline: TI
pros:
TI is well positioned to grow due to very smart business leaders and strategy.  
The business is diverse allowing a lot of opportunity for early career people to get exposure to several different areas.
cons: Human resource practices are archaic.  Many mid/higher mgt roles are not listed and preselected reducing the opportunity for advancement and reducing the pool of best candidates.  Company does not consistently value people.

headline: wafer specialist
pros: I enjoy working at texas instrument for the people.
cons: I wish we still open in hfab.

headline: Intern
pros:
Very Intelligent people to work with.
Workshops to help you with anything.
Texin (sports facility ) is very good.
cons: In my case , clarity about the deliverable was missing .

headline: Team Lead
pros: Work culture, innovative nature of the projects, work life balance
cons: Not on the latest technologies if you are a digital engineer.

headline: GOOD
pros: awesome work culture, live projects, good working environment
cons: no cons as it is at its best

headline: IC Layout Engineer
pros: Steady work for 20 years, the department I worked in was  a small and personal group, like a family. We had cookout's several times a year.  The people were all very professional and communication and collaboration was great.
cons: Management from California, did not understand our design center in Fort Collins, although we were profitable, and all self starters, they no longer wanted to manage us long distance, so they closed our design center.

headline: Well-managed, great benefits
pros: Solid senior leadership, great benefits (healthcare, timebank/vacation, family support), culture of hard work and ethics, passionate employees
cons: Large company that can feel bureaucratic at times, flat organizational structure

headline: Great Experience, Great Values
pros: Not only are they one of the pioneers in engineering but have values worth working for.
cons: The task distribution kind of gets overwhelming but is also backed by really helpful people.

headline: Great
pros: Great job to work for
cons: not any known cons there

headline: Manager
pros: Throws pretty good parties, sometimes.
cons: Worst place to work on Earth. People are treated as chattel, hired in droves, then fired in droves. Management doesn't have a clue about how to organize labor, and they clearly have their favorites when it comes to promotion. I can't say enough awful things about this company.

headline: Verygood company
pros: Good work culture and work life balance
cons: No words to say about this every thing is good

headline: TI
pros: Great profit shaing & benefits.
cons: Beaurocratic and lacks an innovative spirit.

headline: Design engineer
pros: Good benefits,smart people and good technology
cons: Lots of politics and inside play

headline: Good or Bad Depends on the Business Group
pros: Big reputable company. Nice to have on resume
cons:
The company is steering away from digital products. As a result, there are rounds and rounds of layoffs happening in the digital groups. No job security.
As people are being let go, the remaining employees are juggling more works left by employees who are leaving. Work load is huge. When you are burned out, they will just put you in the next round of layoff.
To be fair people in the analog groups are doing ok.

headline: Analog Design Engineer
pros: smart people around, great company to work in, lot of resources available
cons: too much politics and takes erratic decisions with the policies for employee

headline: Fun working in TI
pros: Good work life balance. People are very knowledgeable, hardworking and intelligent. Employees are so passionate about their work. Again last but not the least, a handsome amount of salary in hand.
cons: No major issues found so far. May be I have to stay more time here to find any. But environment in this company is quite fresh. Good environment for freshers also.

headline: Abandon hope all ye who enter here.
pros: None that I can think of.
cons:
Severe decline in value placed on the individual. TI has become a faceless machine that cares for nothing else but the bottom line. Walking the halls, you see nothing but hunched over people who are too scared to leave because they need to feed their families and pay a mortgage. 

To make matters worse, employees are forced to provide their own office supplies. Chairs have broken arms or wheels. The cube walls are old and moldy. 

Seriously, this is a company that has collapsed under the weight of it's past success. Look elsewhere.

headline: Technical Sales Representative
pros:
My review is completely based off of my own experiences. I gave the company 2 stars since I believe that is more of an average rating otherwise I would give it 1. Some people have great experiences based on their organization and manager.

Pro: Pays well for first job out of under grad. You can earn more later though if pay is your major concern (don't believe that they pay you the most)
cons:
I have been at TI for 2 years and I hate to say it but I have had an overall negative experience from the sales training program (TSA) to deploying as a TSR.

HR and Management gives empty promises, tells you what you want to hear to get you to take the job (ex: you can be as technical as you want to be), manager micromanages, toxic environment, encourages employees undermining each other for results, can't be open as people will turn your words against you, training program is lacking compared to your GEs and others who invest a lot in you for proper technical classes and leadership training,

Out-competed by competition in many markets, cutting the supporting group and push entire team to find "merging market" is pretty desperate. Not to mention the impatience and short time line allowed to develop such a new market (usually range from 8-12 months from market research to significant results). headline: Every day was the same, yet different.
pros:
Very well planned Internship, lots of opportunities to learn from your team and also get involved in other teams. You are responsible to deploy EMEA marketing emails and Manage 4 corporate social media channels. Interesting part of the Internship is working with the Sales team to creatively follow up on events and market upcoming events to draw in more customers.

Company is very ethical, with friendly management and a very approachable boss (open door 99% of the time).

Sometimes the work can be overwhelming, but it is important to learn to communicate issues with your Supervisor earlier rather than later and they are always happy to rearrange the deadline or/and even support you in the task if it is a high priority.

For someone like me, who comes from London the city can be quite boring and depressing especially Freising where according to staff working there is also quite boring. However, Freising does have loads to offer if you are here during an Internship.
cons: The core tasks, Email management and Social media management are extremely repetitive in the sense that you will have the same job every day however understandingly these are very important tasks so while I was doing them I was taking a lot of pride especially the Email campaign management. Also, remember that you will be given projects which will be quite different.

headline: Great for a Few Years
pros:
- Socially, there is no hierarchy. It's really easy to be friendly with people at all levels of the company. Getting beers with a director after work as an entry-level program manager is a relatively common occurrence. Conversations with people at all levels of the company will take on tones far more casual than you may expect.

- You demonstrate your value as a resource with your work and especially with the size and strength of your intracompany professional network, not the amount of time you spent at your desk that week. This is truly one of the best, most progressive aspects of TI's culture.

- Working at TI, you will receive a crash course in the "human" side of your discipline (the part they never taught you in school). Getting a project off the ground and working for your customers will require buy-in from about a million other teams before it's possible. At TI, obtaining buy-in can sometimes be an incredibly counter-intuitive process. That is, it doesn't usually mean convincing people your ideas will help the business, but rather convincing them that it's worth it to them to let you proceed. This would be a con, except that making it through this crash course will overprepare you for the political side of jobs at any future employer.

- It is exceptionally easy to move around into different teams at TI. You express an interest, get some recommendations, and you're in.

- They pay well and seem to pride themselves on it. I negotiated poorly and they still had no qualms paying me more than I expected.

- A manager who likes you is a manager who will sponsor all sorts of business trips around the world.
cons: Professionally, the organization is very hierarchical. Entry-level employees do entry-level work, and middle managers at TI likely define "entry-level" differently than you do. I heard the phrase "have to pay your dues" more than once while I worked there. Often, team managers do what program managers normally do, while program managers do what assistants normally do. This can get extremely frustrating as you witness your team's direction slowly evaporate while your manager gets lost in the strategic customer-facing work and you do the time-consuming simple tasks with which he or she would rather not be bothered. This means a 5-person team with a manager and four experts executes like 1 person who has 4 assistants.

cons: The few employees working in the fabs are extremely overworked as T.i management strives to reduce cost of production. Therefore there are more tools to run per employee than humanly possible. Stress level is increased as suprintendents demand more from the already overstretched employee- and by the way mistakes/ accidents are not tolerated. While pay is better than walmart's, T.i could do better especially if you take into account the kind of profits it makes from this overworked employees' work." good luck" moving up- once a manufacturing specialist, you are condemned to stay as one forever.

headline: Process Engineer
pros: Challenges you to be a problem solver. Nice people.Treated with respect. Lots of room to learn about process and equipment. A place to be if you want a career working in the fab.
cons: Asked to support the fab 24/7 when needed. Very busy place, difficult to do things you enjoy and are passionate about. Primarily doing things because of the need. On call all the time. Not much career development, hard to move around for certain positions. Do not easily believe what the interviewers tell you, entered job with lots of false hopes and expectations. The fab role has huge turnover rate, fab management actually want to keep you, but many leave for obvious reasons.

headline: Love-Hate Relationship
pros: Great people, great 'college campus' facility (the one in Dallas, that is), mostly good or better managers, great opportunities to do things with coworkers after hours or even during work hours (company activities, group activities), great community and charity work. Depending on your manager, you may have really great work-life balance, some flexibility with hours, ability to take off early and stay late the next day, etc. Most of the time you will not be denied a vacation request - in fact, I was approved every time.
cons: There has been a 'layoff culture' for so long that even my father (older than I want to admit) heard about this when I was just a little boy living in Dallas and had no idea I'd ever work for TI. Managers are often simply going to toe the company line and won't stand up for what is right or ethical (not talking about ethical practices dealing with customers, rather with employees), Seniority is king, doesn't much matter what you do if you've made it into the structure of the company, even down to the operator level. New ideas are usually squelched as 'that's not the way we do it here'. Hard to make it as a newer employee if your manager and coworkers have been there decades. Upper management is simply unaware of very much that goes on and really couldn't be bothered to remedy it even if they took time to become aware of various situations.

headline: Stable Company

cons: Working for a remote site however, we do not get many of the benefits we would being at headquarters, like the advantage of training classes hosted there, and facilities such as gyms, ect.

- The gratis snacks and drinks (water, pop, etc) are convenient.
cons: If you don't like working on IDEs, then this place may not be for you.  That is the speciality of this office.

headline: Solid place to work if you just want something that pays the bills
pros: Competitive compensation and good work/life balance. Lots of cool company events and programs. It is a pretty easy place to work if you aren't really looking to move up the corporate ladder and you just want to duck your head, do your job, and collect a paycheck. If you are the ambitious type, then expect to play lots of political games.
cons: Highly competitive work environment...sometimes toxic. Lots of politics and backstabbing. It is a "blame" culture. People are afraid to take responsibility for projects or decisions for fear of making a mistake, getting blamed, and having their reputation at TI be destroyed. TI's business fluctuates a lot, so layoffs are fairly common and everyone is always playing a game of musical chairs to avoid them.

TI experience is with high reputation for analog technology, such as power management and high precision analog. With TI experience, it is very easy to jump into big companies or other industries.
cons: The company emphasizes too much on business instead of technology. TI is supposed to be a good engineering base company not business. If employee survives in TI, the technical skill not only is required, also the luck is important. There are too much layoff rounds.

pros: TI invests in employees - there are multiple chances for training and movement within the organization. You will work for very smart people, for the most part. I miss working with engineers who are business-savvy. Lots of opportunities to work on a variety of projects that are meaningful to the company. The people who work there are genuinely GOOD people!

Marketing there can be old-fashioned and behind-the-times. TI is changing the world with their technology but the atmosphere in which you work in is extremely dry.

headline: Conservative company moving in the right direction

headline: Sr Metrology Engineer
pros: Enjoyed the position very much.  I worked well with everyone I came in contact with.  I have nothing but high marks for all engineering I worked with.  The stress level was just right.  Managers and supervisors were always there to help.  Exciting changes all the time.  DLP back-end equipment was one of the best times of my career.
cons: got married and moved out of state.  Was not given enough time to train even thou I gave two months notice.  I was given somebody to train till just days before I left.  Most of my open projects failed because of that.  I felt bad but had to disconnect due to relocating issues.  Since then, I have tried to come back and can't even get a email back with any applications I have sent in.

headline: Very hostile culture

Relationship building with the customer is of no value to sales management.

headline: Disappointed at the end.
pros:
TI provides great benefits: competitive salary, annual stock options and  grants, employee stock purchase plan, vacation, 401K with matching, profit sharing and sales bonus if in sales department.
Great portfolio for every application. Unbeatable price for their customers. 
Great factory and support staff. Competent technical and sales staff.
cons:
It seems like TI has turned into less innovation and more me too, low cost product company.
Hiring fresh engineering graduate students with no real experience and after short in-house training assign them as sales engineers supporting customers. As expected some don't make it.
Sales staff are unhappy with the latest company accounting practices, finding this immortalizing and wasteful.
Sales staff performance is highly effected by constant price discounting.
Some Senior management believes is leading with fear, intimidation and bullying.

headline: Nice place to work, layoffs every year
pros: Nice, benefits, great life-work balance, flexible hours. A lot of very talented people.
cons: They tend to lay people off with little warning pretty much every year. Contractors are usually let go in mid December, permanent employees - at the end of January. Every year management says "We are done with the layoffs" only to let go of more people at the end of the year. This is a dying group at TI that produces a dying technology - calculators.

headline: Endless re-orgs and RIFs year after year.  No clear direction other than "Analog is the way, move to Dallas"
pros: Flexible work schedules.  Comp time.  Good people to work with.
cons: Leadership that cares only about the bottom line.  Short term means "last week".  Long term means "at the end of the month."  TI puts the "ti" in "reactive".

headline: Solid company
pros: Very stable. Incredibly ethical. Smart engineer peers. Good benefits.
cons: Hesitant to adopt change suggested from employees. Older workforce. Conservative culture.

headline: It was a good place to start my career
pros: Very smart people, lots of freedom to do your job, opportunities to develop into an expert, good work/life balance.
cons: Deep staff cuts over a multi-year period have eroded job security and have resulted in a massive brain-drain from the company.

headline: Product / Test Engineer
pros: Good salary and benefits. Lots of stuff to do and learn for new engineer. If you are fresh from college, good place to work. But if you look for long term career, you should not work for TI.
cons: This company managers are very politic. They have very little respect for employee.  If you are not good at people skills you will not survive long. Good at technical only will not survive long either. TI had a clear history of laying off people.

headline: Very good company
pros: Cutting edge technology and great team
cons: Many re-orgs and multi-site work

headline: Started my career and grew up there
pros: They have a good culture of people development and I grew a lot in my career there with the help of some great managers and mentors.  Compensation was good for the area and I was able to take risks and work on some awesome products.  I have no regrets about the time I spent there and still talk to many former colleagues.
cons:
Too frugal with equipment. Once I had an employee whose laptop had issues to the point of being unusable and it took months to get approval for the replacement. 

TI has a proud, rich history of innovation, but it seems to be fading in recent years as the focus has moved to simpler chips with a lower R&D cost.

headline: Work-Life balance
pros: Engineering centered company that strives to innovate and win.  Benefits package is competitive with industry standards.  Opportunity to grow/develop in a variety of roles.  Very talented employee base.
cons: Difficult to find work-life balance since the company manufactures on a global 24/7 operation.  While the company has a good profit-sharing program to compensate employees, it only does a mediocre job of rewarding high performers through it's pay-for-performance philosophy.  Results don't translate to monetary recognition.

headline: Texas Instruments provided me many years of a decent wage and good benefits.
pros:
Texas Instruments provided competitive wages, good benefits, and training opportunities that gave knowledge for the job and for safety (which benefitted the employee for work or home). 
Texas Instruments was good at keeping their employees informed of the company's performance and the individual's performance.
cons: At times, the supervisors needed to be more encouraging and supportive to the operators.

headline: good place to work
pros: big company, focus on sales/management
cons: less flexible for the process

headline: Great company to work for
pros:
There are multiple opportunities and paths to take within TI
Great Benefits, and great people to work with in all departments
cons: As with any large company. It can take time to accomplish small tasks

headline: Experience in IT, but applicable elsewhere in the company
pros: Extremely ethical company. Strong financially. Compensation is pretty good. Decent amount of vacation. They are finally updating most of the buildings, which were in very bad shape previously.
cons:
The work/life balance is getting out of hand. Since 2009, many jobs have been offshored. Working with these coworkers requires lots of nights on the US employees' part and introduces extra work and delay, simply because of the time difference. Flex schedules and part-time are becoming a farce--if you go part time, you will never truly work 75%, but you most definitely be paid at that rate. 

Experienced employees are being replaced exclusively by new grads (or not at all). While the quality of these new grads is high, they need time to learn and be trained. This leads to extra work being dumped on existing employees and inadequate training and inappropriately large workloads for new hires. There seems to be a big gap in middle-aged (30s) employees and the knowledge gap is going to be huge in a few years when key people retire and all that is left is people with 3-5 years of experience--who tend to jump ship more often.

The pace keeps increasing to the point that employees are burned out. The long hours and hard work that were previously rewarded and appreciated are now expected 100% of the time with little regard to how it is affecting resource morale and work/life balance. Managers are good at reassuring us that they will push back when needed, but it never happens in practice.

It has been made very clear by upper management that IT is a cost and we are definitely 2nd tier corporate citizens.

headline: Field Sales Engineer
pros: Great people and ethical culture. Texas is also an awesome place for lifestyle and has a vibrant technology industry.
cons: too conservative in terms of how they approach going after big opportunities and creating new parts for customers. need more aggressive and creative edge to win out in the marketplace.

headline: Mediocre at best…the grass is definitely greener
pros:
+High salaries relative to market

+Flexible work arrangements (but only if your manager supports this or likes you…many managers will say no, or guilt trip you if you work from home with no reason).  Flexibility is only a benefit if it's consistently applied for everyone, not just those employees with children.

+Great experience for early career folks (stretch roles with a lot of responsibility)

+Large amount of new college grads starting every year, easy to build up a great group of friends if you're a transplant to Dallas

+Opportunities to work in international locations

+Relatively flat org structure
cons:
-If you work here, expect to work 24/7.  Work/life balance is virtually nonexistent.  I work at another company now, and I have never been happier.  TI was my first job out of college, so I thought this was normal.  It's not!  Don't be scared of trying something new if you're not happy.

-"Old boys club" culture.  Comms and HR are trying hard to turn it around and offer fun activities like Jack Kilby Day, but as long as the company is full of disgruntled people, the culture will definitely not be turning around anytime soon.  

-Lack of transparency around processes/procedures, especially compensation cycle, leads to employees distrusting HR

-Forced distribution rankings for performance = getting zeroed out for yearly raises, even when there is not a known performance concern.  Very bad for morale/engagement!  Especially in suffering business units.

headline: Great Company to work in, not so great people around
pros: Great company, Culture, Work ethics, Technical development, salary

headline: Engineering vs Non-technical.
pros:
Product engineering(PE) is where the number 1 picks of engineering graduates go. Recently they hire the best graduates from schools for this position but only IF a position is available.
Very challenging environment. A lot of technical trainings. In turn, a big expectation from you.
Continuous learning.
TI is the best semicon industry(see the records). Not the best salary though.
cons:
Other groups does not seem to know your job. they think you are doing nothing at all.
They have little respect for engineering groups(not just PE).
Non engineering groups are not very supporting and are very demanding. They seem to think that we should support them, but in fact should be the other way around.
No unity. Very divided.
Poor work life balance(shifting schedules)

cons:
Too many tapeouts of half baked ICs- you work extra hours to make sure that the IC is sent to fab and later that product is shelved..after a while you start to wonder whether the management has a clear plan
Too much emphasis on sales- that being said, there are a few teams where the emphasis is on R&D.
Work life im-balance- most of the year especially close to tape-outs design/layout engineers spend late nights and weekends in office. After the IC comes back from fab, it is the turn of the test engineers to work late.

headline: Good Company to work for.

* For the most part they focus on the important metrics
cons:

headline: Good company with analog/embedded focus

Good work environment, friendly coworkers 
Good NCG program
Flexible working time, 
Many trainings
cons:
The compensation and benefits package are different for different regions, some local policy does not fit the company culture.

headline: Waste of time
pros: Nothing to say other than maybe office location
cons: No room to move up. Lots of politics.

headline: No concern for their people's lives
pros: Nice campus, you may have a relaxed work environment, depending on your boss.
cons: You can be let go at any time. I knew one man who worked his whole career at TI (forty years) and was never laid off. I know another who hasn't been laid off and he has worked there about twenty years, but they are the only two I know personally like that after working for the company for about fifteen years. Many people have been laid off one or more times. Luckily, it is possible to get back on at TI after layoffs, but one has to be lucky and find his own position - there is no such thing as 'being called back' after layoffs, as many people ask me and assume.

headline: Working at Texas Instruments
pros:

There is a constant push to improve processes - to make processes more efficient and not accept things as is
Great work/life balance (of course depends on the type of role you are in)
Flexibility in work schedule as far as ability to work from home
Great benefits for top performers - options, RSUs etc.
cons:
Base salary increases are nominal

cons: Can be long work hours, but the benefits seem decent, and I so far have been happy with management and management styles.

headline: Best company to work for
pros: Good innovative environment.  Knowledgeable peers. Flexibility of learning new things. Challenging projects to work. Open to new ideas. Good company for growth.
cons: Changing buisiness priorities with market

headline: Great company
pros: Promotions were given only to those who had a killer work ethic and I was not one of them I think anyone who works hard will do well
cons: Challenging hours to work there since I had to travel so much I was away from my home many nights during the week

headline: Great corporation !
pros:
state of the art technologies, fair compensation package, excellent working place and facilities, opportunity to evolve in a truly international environment (both TI sites over the world and international customers)
Expat packages are really generous
cons:
- difficult to move internally or be relocated to other TI sites abroad
- too heavy management, slow decision process
- lack of visibility on the global strategy, little room for initiatives

headline: Texas Instruments is a very good company to work for.
pros: TI has a very diverse in their hiring.  They offer employees and contractors many perks and amenities.  The work atmosphere is friendly and casual.  They provide many opportunities for job advancement.
cons: Due to the nature of the business, it is either feast or famine.  Layoffs are always looming and you don't have the feeling of job stability.  The compensation and retirement packages are not always as generous as they should be.

headline: Great Learning Experience
pros: Very challenging, benefits are fair, compensation is good!
cons: Poor Atmosphere, hard work goes unnoticed

headline: Good but could have been better
pros: Big company, so a lot of different kinds of experience is possible. Lateral movement is possible across groups. The company gives you decent benefits. The salary is average in the industry. However employees get a very good exposure, something which is very important atleast at the beginning of your career. You can switch careers as it is a big company and there are different opportunities.
cons:
However the company policies and management structure makes you do dependable on one person, that is your manager. They have not implemented matrix management or cross management structure, which makes an employee very vulnerable to the whims of the managerial hierarchy.
They take away your normal holidays even for genuine medical leave (atleast most managers do that), which is something they can improve on. Specially if you are an international working on H1B, you need more than a few days a year to travel to your home country.

headline: Great place to start and learn, but ultimately just another stifling and politicized corporate sweatshop
pros: You will be given as much responsibility as you show you can handle, quickly, and will have lots of opportunity to learn new skills.  If you have deep specialization in areas that are important to the business you will (probably) have pretty good job security - as long as the company stays in that business area.
cons:
Entitlement mentality towards uncompensated labor from middle and upper management.  Highly political and sometimes bullying environment, entrenched mediocrity in middle management, "blame the troops" backstabbing from incompetents.  Managers and employees who understand and accept the status quo of "needing" to be highly political take credit for the work of others who won't or haven't figured out how to play the political game.  Unspoken but well known mafia system where those who get made survive all layoffs regardless of whether they maintain their business or technical edge, and get to wet their beaks at the bonus pool whether they put in a strong contribution for the year or not.  Company and upper management shift the product strategy and cede markets to nimbler competitors with regularity.  Poor documentation & dissemination of company specific technical knowledge means that such knowledge resides only with those who are willing to throw work/life balance in the trash and do organizationally inefficient individual from-scratch learning (basically reverse engineering the company's own IP), creating a perverse differentiator for compensation and advancement , a two-class technical staff, and key personnel risks for the company.  

If you are a talented and creative individual, you are selling yourself incredibly short by becoming a lifer here.

headline: Bail out of this sinking ship while you can
pros:
- Sychophant management
- Managers try to exploit workers down the line
cons:
- More you try to do a good job- more you be rewarded with grunt work and 'overtime work' except there is no overtime
- Other companies Samsung, HITACHI and every other microchip maker leave them in the dust.
- Adding a tiny new feature to an existing chip- or 1 mw less power doesn't usher in innovation- wake up and smell the fertilizer.

headline: great benefits and salaries
pros: culture, opportunities, salaries, technology, location
cons: perks, office facilities, parking, cafeteria

headline: Full of energy and innovation
pros: Great minds to work with
cons: Not so great work life balance

headline: A very dinamic and fast moving company.
pros: Salary level is above average. You can learn a lot about discipline and processes. Easy to sell products, good portfolio.
cons: Fluctuation is high. The Board spends too much time on reviewing the field puting extremely high pressure on managers, therefore people are escaping the company. The relatively high fluctuation in every level combined with having no CRM system causes loss of valuable knowledge and relationship.

headline: My experience in TI was good

headline: Started right out of college.  The company is trying to get younger and relies heavily on new college grads.
pros: Ethics is large part of the organization, and speaking what is right is not punished.  Health benefits are good, and there is a great opportunity to get extensive real world experience that is often held for employees with more tenure.  Flex-time can be used, which really helps when you have nightly calls with Asia.  Challenging work, and a great opportunity to work with smart people.
cons: two different cultures in the Analog and Embedded processing segments.  Work life balance is difficult to have when the job demands are more than the people to complete the job.  Diversity can take priority to merit.

headline: TI review
pros: Great place to work.  Smart people, allowed to do whatever you have the nerve to tackle, reward performance well, international travel and work opportunities abound
cons: big company therefore some bueracacy

headline: Prone to layoffs

headline: A good company that if  they would choose, could be the best.
pros: In the best of times, it can be exciting and fun. If you are an engineer you can be challenged if you want with many different groups to be a part of. Pay is typical but less than what you may get in Silicon Valley. If you like to travel, you can often do that too! Your experience will vary with each group... Some are better than others. Benefits are very very good and more than fair. The company has been very good to me. I hesitantly would recommend it....But
cons: Once you hit 50 years old, watch out. TI is well known for kicking older workers to the curb. How they are able to do this systematically is beyond me...well maybe not. They simply pay off each individual with take it or leave it "packages" where you promise not to tell. Secondly, they use the H1B visa  workers  like crack. This is mostly to keep pay down I suppose. These are harsh comments but it's well known in the industry.

headline: Nice people, the culture is a bit conservative.

cons:

- Work can be monotonous depending on your role.

Some benefits have changed for the bad over the years that I worked for T.I. such as retirement medical.  When I started working there, medical was paid in full for the retiree.  Not so any longer.  I'm not complaining as it is still better than buying a O-Bama plan.

headline: Amazing and Employee friendly Workplace
pros: The company is very much employee friendly. The workplace culture i think would be among the best in Semiconductor companies in India. You need not do same kind of work again and again if you get bored. Much flexibility is there for people to change the teams. All the senior level employees are very friendly in nature and are always there for help when you feel stuck at something. The best part is the separate playing and recreational area which is open to employees even in the working hours and on weekends as well. Sports covered include- Lawn Tennis, Volleyball, Badminton, Football, Table Tennis, Music Room , Meditation Room and high class Gym. Employees are encouraged to take part in sports and other activities along with the work to have a proper work life balance. I don't think such
cons: For Digital department company looks in a little low confidence. Already did two layoffs- one in Nov 2012 and another one in March 2014. So this is the only con which i found.

headline: one of the best places to work
pros: The kind of learning you get at TI is unparalleled to anywhere else.  As long as you are doing the right thing, no one stops you from doing what you would like even in an exploratory fashion. Moreover the kind of respect in general that you get at TI and the culture , even though much degraded from what it was before is still better than most other MNCs in India. Also the opportunity to work beyond India and in a more global leadership role is far more available and acceptable in TI India than in other MNCs in India.
cons: For very senior experience levels, opportunities are less in India, especially on the business or management side, If you are doing pure technical work, there are far more opportunities. So growth after a point even if you're a star performer, becomes slightly tough.

headline: Good place to work, Upper management needs direction

The work and the projects are definitely cutting edge and you work with some of the smartest people out there. There's always an abundance of things to do and people all over the world to work with. You can always find something new and exciting to work on.
Flexible work arrangements means you can actually work from home and they have a lot of programs setup to help employees out.
cons: Compensation is pretty average, bonuses are below average, and the time bank system is a bit odd. Benefits are below average from what I've seen other companies provide and they keep cutting back on how much they'll spend on benefits and the perks that are provided seem to keep disappearing. Too much management in the way to get an idea heard and new projects are slow to get through the system to get traction on due to old style management structure.

One of colleagues, his eyes got problem while working, he sees double images and need to put his face near 13" laptop screen in 10 cm. Then finally he got a bigger LCD. But he is in LOA now and his eyes hardly to recover. Manager or leaders still won't give you bigger screen unless your eyes have specific problem.

headline: Good colleagues. Ok work, bad management, less pay compared to other semiconductor companies in Munich area
