Company is cash driven. As soon as they see some losses they decide to downsize.
HR department is worst. No room to negotiate.

Betriebsrat is "namesake". They work on commands from HR. So pretty useless to expect any support from them!

headline: Every time the brass ring is in reach, the company drops the ball
pros: Good people for the most part, flexible environment. Usually good opportunities to work in different areas.
cons: The company is obsessive about re-justifying every business decision over and over, until the focus is no longer on increasing revenue and profitability. Endless business reviews take the place of actually supporting customers and winning business. Company will commit to a business today, then decide to kill it the next day. Just really a lack of focus. The company is much smaller than it used to be, now focusing on more commodity business than higher margin products.

headline: Good place to work, lots of talented people
pros: Very good benefits & compensation, with opportunities for profit sharing. Most all of the people you work with are extremely talented. Good opportunities to work on new technologies and products. Cool to know that things you work on show up in recognizable consumer products.
cons:
Big company
Stress level at times can be high to deliver
Company will make tough decisions to get out of a business if it isn't hitting the performance goals they want - result is entire BUs can be hit resulting in RIFs.

headline: Terrible sales strategy and management culture
pros: Great product portfolio and product line management/people
cons: incompetent sales management ineffective sales strategy

headline: Great place to work
pros: Stable, ethical company with great people that really care about the company and like their work.
cons: As with most large companies, projects can be difficult to move forward due to multiple reasons (cost restrictions, policies, etc.). Sometimes suffers from too many chefs in the kitchen syndrome, too many different groups wanting things done their way or not at all.

headline: design engineer
pros: great place to work, good benefits
cons: political issues that you need overcome

headline: ok company
pros: good culture, stable and ethical.
cons: pay is just ok and too many re-organization's

headline: Massive company with constant change at mid-management level
pros: It really varies by location. Dallas is not the same as Santa Clara, Munich or Bangalore. If you're a in-the-trenches engineer in a stable group, you have the benefit of a relatively stable company with plenty of resources.
cons:
Whether you are an individual contributor or a manager, be prepared for constant management change. Growth at all costs is the mantra. This causes very short-term orientation. Most low-level managers seem to live in fear and mid-level managers are constantly trying to climb. 

This also causes HR to have way too much organizational power. Not good long-term.

headline: Good till it lasts...
pros: Good people to work with; hardworking, intelligent and talented.
cons: Constant fear of layoffs. Old school approach. Treat employees like a commodity - no value to hardworking and talented employees....

headline: cash driven company
pros: many job opportunities, very interesting job, possibility to work from home, very good tools and material for employees
cons:
young and unexperienced management team (in germany)
work never  stop since it is an international environment

headline: Great place to grow
pros: I started as an entry level IT.  They really help you grow as a team member as well as a person.
cons: I can't think of any.  This place is great place to work.  I would love to go back if I ever enter the working world again.

headline: Overall experience is ok.
pros: Pay and benefits are ok.  Work and life can be balanced.
cons: There is a lot of politics.  Upper management does not care about individual employees.  There is too much reorganization in most BUs every year.

headline: Texas Instruments has a great work environment and knows how to grow employees!
pros: I started Texas Instruments in an entry level job and TI spent a lot of time and money to develop me as a leader.  They provide tuition reimbursement and also sent me to numerous training classes for technical topics as well as leadership and other soft skills topics.
cons: Not the highest salaries in the market, and they are known for large sweeping layoffs.  One of which eliminated my position there.

headline: lost potential
pros: Good work/life balance, low stress level. Good vacation. Plentiful design tools. Lots of support for design engineers i.e. in the lab and design software. Could have potential but see the cons.
cons: perhaps it depends on particular BU, but in my experience there is way too much politics and not enough substance. Many of SMTS/DMTS are old and not up to the level, but still have their high titles and perks and not shy to use them. Mid-level management is often technically mediocre resulting in loss of business and subsequent mass lay-offs. Tech ladder advancement is based on who you know, not what one is worth. Low-level management often stuffed by incompetents who just sing the company tune but have no clue of design issues and just concerned with keeping themselves employed.  Nat Semi acquisition was sought to add tech talent, but Nat Semi was never in the top 3 of analog, and many of their best people left. Recent lay-offs tended to remove a lot of talent - those who stayed seemed most politically skilled, not technically talented, consequently a lot of talent got picked up by top competitors, probably on the cheap.  Top management comes from sales and marketing, not from design, which probably accounts for a lot of the above issues. I can't see how TI can compete with the top 3 in analog - other than on price.

headline: Like a Family... with way too many personal issues
pros: When I first started here, I was told by current employees TI = Training Institute and Tiny Income. I don't believe this to be true. They reward hard work and effort, and they have reasonable expectations for work/life balance.
cons: TI was like a family to me... but a dysfunctional one. Politics are horrible. Also, mass layoffs really hurt the culture.

headline: Challenging and rewarding
pros: TI is one of the most ethical companies in the world.  It is also one of the few companies that gives substantial profit sharing to all employees.  Telecommuting is encouraged.
cons: Too many reorgs.  In my division, these basically halted progress for a week or more at a time, and new managers rarely understood the accomplishments and capabilities of their "new" employees.

headline: Systems Engineer
pros: There are lots of opportunities to get your hands into so sometimes you can find yourself over loaded and over worked. Many sub groups that work on different technologies.  Generally a high caliber of professionals.
cons: Very metric oriented. Many subgroups so this can be a negative as well since there is high turn over and can get confusing on who is working on what.

headline: Solid technical company that changes focus too often
pros: Challenging jobs with lots of opportunities to work hard.  Room to take on more responsibilities at any job level.   Heavy international travel in senior positions.  Great experience for a first job
cons: Not much work life ballance.  Focused on loading everyone as heavily as possible.  Senior workers are slowly pushed out of the organization around 50.   Most promotions go to individuals under 30.

headline: Senior Sales and Marketing Professional
pros: good work environment , rewarding professionals
cons: internal coordination can be better

headline: review based on internship
pros:
good work culture
good values
very helping mentors
cons: work hard to climb the technical ladder

headline: review based on internship
pros:
good work culture
good values
very helping mentors
cons: work hard to climb the technical ladder

headline: Systems Engineer
pros: Friendly environment and good benefit
cons: Lack of investment and sales oriented culture

headline: design engineer
pros: good big company with a lot of people
cons: too south part of the country

headline: Not a great place for digital engineers
pros:
1. Latest technology
2. Lot of responsibilities. Good chance to learn a lot
3. You will get to work with the best people in the industry
4. Flexible timings and great compensation
cons:
1. Poor work life balance. Long meetings (5~6 hours a day). Will end up putting 16 hours a day at work overall. 
2. No job security. Layoff is a quarterly ritual. Will be working with a knife under the neck
3. Company is more focused toward analog business. Not a good place for digital engineers.

headline: Managing perception
pros: Large established  infrastructure worldwide, good benefits in the US.
cons:
Just like leaders of many other publicly traded companies TI managers are mostly focused on impressing investors. This culture spreads through all levels of the company. It does not matter what you do, it only matters what your boss think you do.
 The company has very few innovative products. Product designed decades ago generate most of the revenue.

headline: Experienced Hires Beware
pros: Company is actively managing the business portfolio to make itself more competitive.  Quick to make decisions about which businesses to nurture and which ones to cut their losses.
cons: The work culture feels very old from the calculator days.  It's also an entrenched culture and you frequently here "that's the way we've always done it."  There is no formal process to onboard you and little assistance is offered to help you navigate the organizational landmines.  When you ask questions about why things are the way they are, you often get a confused look because it is so embedded in their day-to-day it is not recognizable to them.  Also no formal performance review process is conducted.  Your annual salary adjustment is the primary feedback on performance.

headline: Great place to work at as long as you have your head on your shoulders
pros: Generally friendly colleagues; easy going yet hard working environment; very good products.
cons: No significant opportunities for advancement or lateral moves, unless at the larger US sites; processes rather ad hoc; some office politics to deal with.

headline: Ethical and stable company
pros:
Compensation is per industry average, high performers and managers are paid very well
Benefits are one of the best in semiconductor industry, takes good care of its employees.
No system of punching/punching out..so flexi-time. Good gym and sports facilities
Good infrastructure within the office..more or less everything is streamlined.
Strong focus on ethics..maybe one of the most ethical companies in this industry.
Very good company to work for if your skill set matches with what the company is looking for!
cons:
Almost everyone is a good performer...promotions are very tough as compared to other companies..too much competition. Career growth will never be great..though salary increments might be good.
Lot of variation in pay within the same job grade...
Like most other MNCs, the career opportunities if you are working in US for the same company are better compared to in India.

headline: TI
pros: very good engineers and long term employees
cons: frequent re-orgs, marketing more important than engineering, Internally it is a group of many small companies, very conservative and risk averse.

headline: Good company to work for.
pros: One of the few companies left in America whom actually have semiconductor foundry.  You get to learn silicon hands on.
cons: It is very difficult to fix mistakes once silicon is cast.  Work-around solutions will not fix the problems.  It is chasing-your-tail problem.

headline: Management Chain needs a major shakeup
pros: Texas Instruments has a great history with a global footprint and many Smart people ruwho have stuck around through the turbulent recent past can make this company great once again.
cons: The entire company is run like a Sales team. Long term vision means thinking about 4 Quarter during the first Quarter. Texas Instruments really needs to shed it's Inbred management of Sales people and hire some experienced and qualified technology executives. There is no technology company in the world that can continue to grow and prosper by spending more money on SG&A than R&D (take a look at their 2013 Annual report)

headline: Good Place to work but..
pros: Super work culture, awesome and talented people, Good salaries
cons: Frequent team changes. Frequent changes in management

headline: Great place to work.
pros: Innovation and creativity make it very enjoyable to work at TI.   Lots of room to grow.
cons: Sometimes people are promoted beyond their capabilities and are expected to grow into the role.  Unfortunately, many do not make it and not only disrupt their own careers but the work environment of others.

headline: review on TI
pros: Location. Reasonable work load. Flexible work environment.
cons: Too much focused on financial status. No focus on future technical leadership. Low job security.

headline: Good employer
pros: good advancement opportunities....   have consistented provided job rotation chances.    This is a good company to work for.
cons: Some of the jobs are moving out of the country to low-cost areas.  Hopefuly that will change as we move forward.

headline: Good experience, good culture
pros: good culture, good benefits, good work life balance
cons: may not be for everyone

headline: Overall a great experience.
pros: Great bunch of people. Hard working.  Pay was very good.
cons: People are looking out for themselves and their friends.  No company loyalty.

headline: Field Application Engineer
pros: Texas instruments is a cool company with a great local team. I found a chance to follow industry leading technologies very close. I was able to get training in technical and sales. Company car is also a handy perk.
cons: The schedule was getting very tight sometimes. One need to travel lot.

headline: Good learning. Not sure about future
pros: Flexible company. Good learning & personal growth
cons: Not sure about where the company is headed.

headline: Great company
pros: Great education for the employees and career prospect. Nice environment and accessible managers.
cons: Fast changing and many political issues

headline: Best place to work - literally!
pros: Work culture; work culture and work culture
cons: Business decisions and growth perspectives.

headline: Good company, bad digital business and decisions
pros:
Good work culture 
Industry leading pay
Sense of ownership and responsibility 
Technically strong teams
Good Hr policies and people practice
cons:
Digital business not doing well and future looks bleak. But its the best for analog guys. 
2 successive big layoffs worldwide in the digital business. 
No transparency in internal job change.

headline: Good company
pros: good work-life balance, nice environment
cons: need to improve senior management tactics

headline: excellent
pros: good compensation , friendly environment
cons: unfair treatment of those sub-cons

headline: IC Design Engineering
pros: TI provides a great learning environment with lots of infrastructure.  It has solid foundation of people, experience, and products.  Plenty of opportunity for growth.
cons: It is a very large company with large company issues.  Easy to get lost in the crowd.  Hard to tell if my work really impacts the bottom line.

headline: Great in technology, but life and work balance should be improved tremendously.
pros: Challenging, reasonable pay and perk, large resources of knowledge.  Very good environment for single to gain experiences before moving to more life/work balance companies or for married engineers.
cons: This is not a good place for married engineers even though pay, benefits, and time off are very reasonable or a little above average.  Management pays too much attention to getting things out, but does not pay enough attention to quality of products or employees' lives.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: great work life balance, generous compensation
cons: Lots of periodical lay offs happening.

headline: Frustrating and disappointing
pros: Pay and benefits are good for Texas. Work can be interesting but generally too compartmentalized. There is technical challenge available but are generally overwhelmed by institutional deficiencies.
cons: First to middle levels of management are pretty hopeless. Too much work going overseas. Too much work being done by short term contractors so no continuity of effort. Engineering process is fractured at best but realistically it is broken.

headline: I learn things that is very useful to use in other line of work.
pros:
The training was very good learning experince. for all the 21yrs that I was there. I  work in all areas in photo.
Then I transfer to plasma I was full train in that area on all tool set.  I love the training I got in all.
cons: It was hard to get time-off when it came to vacation time,holidays if your time is less than your co-workers they have first pick.

headline: The Walmart of Semiconductors
pros: Focus on cost optimization. Good pay for what you do.
cons: No room for imagination, innovation and risk taking. Can be stressful if you are engaged in a highly visibie activity. Management implements a standardized approach for most business activities. You spend a lot of time on endless reports.

headline: Headed for trouble
pros: They actually pay what you are promised.  Many of the people are great to work with and very talented.  Good opportunities for minorities and women.
cons: Ageism is rampant.  All contrarian views are squashed as part of the culture.  Management opportunities are reserved only for those that are "yes" people.  Culture of micromanagement is become rampant and causing employees to miss other things that should be important.  Innovation and risk taking not encouraged and even short term failures are punished rather than analyzed, reviewed and learned from.

headline: Fourteen years with a great company.
pros: Huge variety of jobs: semiconductor Manufacturing and Engineering, Finance and Operations, Facilities Engineering, Worldwide Procurement and Logistics, Business Operations, Program Management.
cons: Because it's a 24/7/365 worldwide business, there is no end to the work and the job, though exciting, never ends. Work/Life balance rarely seems to be in favor of life.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Relaxed atmosphere, competitive pay, profit-sharing, and great co-workers.
cons: Sometimes people are let go, but that happens everywhere.

headline: No direction
pros: I enjoyed the people I worked with.
cons: Management has no clear direction on what they want the company to produce.

headline: Great Corporate Philosophy
pros: Internal training is good, work flexibility
cons:
TI "old timers" not open to other ways / new processes of doing things.
Married to same vendors every project.  
Very difficult to get new vendors approved for work

headline: Texas Instruments is a company driven by sales more than technology
pros: TI is a big semiconductor company allowing variety of opportunities. It does a fair job on aspect of work-life balance for employ from flexible work schedule, benefit, mother's room, diversity, etc.
cons: TI strategy is driven more and more by sales, operation and profit. There has been too often and too many changes that cause instability and therefore high attrition rate now.

headline: Great company to work in
pros: Colleagues with good working attitudes and commitment.
cons: Bad location as it is way out of town

headline: Great place to start and develop a career.
pros: Low cost of living in DFW, many opportunities for advancement in the company, market competitive compensation.
cons: Very frequent organizational and management changes.

headline: Challenging but rewarding opportunity.
pros: TI is a financially stable corporation. The company is able to keep reinventing itself making it very competitive firm in the semiconductors'  industry.
cons: There should be improvements in the Work/Life balance. There is a lot of pressure on the Manufacturing team in the fabs. The personnel in the Wafer Fabs are very productive. I believe we ask a lot more out of the few employees than what was asked in the past.

headline: Good while it lasted.
pros: Good work life balance. High flexibility in work hours and schedule. Opportunities exist to venture into cross functional disciplines. Lot of opportunity to learn new things and for training.
cons: Top heavy, very few chances for promotion.  No new growth in digital areas. Instead the company is getting out of digital businesses. Communication from management could be better.

headline: Good place for me, and as a company
pros: Great Team, chance to live my hobbies at work. Team focussing both on technical details and efficient execution. Still flexible in many ascpects, despite being a large company.
cons: Occasionall interest in self-profiling of own team vs. (internally) competing teams, and see someone re-inventing the wheel just because no one happened to know the first solution.

headline: I was working in probe production floor, qualifying new set of devices
pros: training is good and you have lot of friends
cons: stand alone for more that 8 hours.

headline: Good Work Life Balance
pros: Good Work Life Balance. Good compensation and have great opportunities to learn.
cons: Too easy to get lost in the crowd.

headline: it is fun to learn but feel like not a lot of PLM wants to spend money on development
pros: A lot of talent people working here..
cons: Management has to pay more attention to growth of their employee..

headline: Communication Infrastructure Business Development Manager
pros: Great people, benefits, work environment -- when far from corporate headquarters in Dallas.
cons: TI Business planning is mostly tactical with little long term strategic planning. PFO is more important than technology.

headline: Great growing experience
pros: I enjoy working here because I've learnt a lot and met some great people
cons: Sometimes tasks get a bit repetitive and boring

headline: Execllent
pros: Great benefits, solid employer.
cons: Difficult to advance in the company.

headline: good work culture
pros:
flexible timings
nice people to work with
sports facilities
cons: lack of risk taking ability

headline: great experience and mentors throughout my time at TI
pros: growth, mentorships, challenges, collaboration throughout department
cons: leadership, meeting customer needs was a challenge with management decisions

headline: Good Old Fashioned Corporate America
pros: There is opportunity for travel and you can easily see how your work impacts the bottom line. It is a sales/revenue focused company.
cons: It is a sales/revenue focused company through and through. Almost all of upper management is from sales and they won't spare much in the way of "nice to haves" for employees. This is no Google; everything centers around increasing profit/revenue. Everything.

headline: Good Old Fashioned Corporate America
pros: There is opportunity for travel and you can easily see how your work impacts the bottom line. It is a sales/revenue focused company.
cons: It is a sales/revenue focused company through and through. Almost all of upper management is from sales and they won't spare much in the way of "nice to haves" for employees. This is no Google; everything centers around increasing profit/revenue. Everything.

headline: good old boys club
pros: corporate strategy is right, stock price following
cons: promotions depend simply on who likes you and what niche you can fill

headline: Good place to work if you dont mind putting in that extra bit
pros: Flat hierarchy, opportunities, Good people
cons: Terrible for work-life balance, can get very frustrating

headline: Great company as first job
pros: Very smart people to work with. Very collaborative environment. Can learn as much as you want. Excellent culture to get mentors and mentoring others. Excellent compensation. Overall good work life balance.
cons: Only people on the fast track seem to get career advances. Upper management not capable and short sighted. Good at the identifying a new market and get in quickly, but not able to fully captivate the market. Always exit quickly whenever things not looking good, lack of long term commitment and investment to any true gamer-changing technologies.

headline: Great Company with good culture and work-life balance
pros:
-Competitive Salary and good benefits
-Good culture
-Great facilities (gym,cafeteria, various sports)
-Friendly work culture
-Flexible timings
-Good Technical Exposure
-Flexibility to move across domains
cons:
-For freshers scope of work is limited initially but you will have good scope if you are involved in a project from beginning
-Currently TI scaled down digital operations in India but still one of the best for analog

headline: good pay, engineers try to make business succeed despite management best efforts to crash it into the ground.
pros: good benefits. good experience. lots of smart people to work with and learn from.
cons: cutthroat culture, business units get shutdown without warning and quite often.

headline: Lead System Engineer
pros: Great culture, friendly employees good work
cons: Nothing much to say about it.

headline: Stable Company
pros: Employee empowerment, Robust Training, Job stability
cons: Slow career growth. Low pay.

headline: Nice place to work at
pros:
1. Flat hierarchy
2. Open discussions with good culture
3. Flexible working hours
cons:
1. Can get into execution mode easily and not always heed personal growth
2. Code quality isn't given priority as much as delivery time

headline: Ok technically, but management is short sighted.
pros: High performers get paid big bucks.  Technology is top notch.
cons:
Managment makes poor business decisions and the end result is management remains in place but engineers get laid off.  

Groups work in silos here with little sharing or cooperation.  

Can get pigeon holed doing certain designs or tasks.

headline: Hardware Company, Not committed to software
pros: Great company. Good hardware products
cons: lousy sales management that only cares about themselves

headline: Lots of opportunities in engineering
pros: Many opportunities for growth and movement
cons: Large company that is silo-ed

headline: Friendly but not a place to grow
pros: This is a good place to work if you are just starting out. It offers you an opportunity to get to know the "ins and outs" of the semiconductor field.
cons: Mental stimulation and growth are quite deficient at times. You really get the vibe that you are a "cog in the wheel" while working here.

headline: Too much politics
pros: Competitive salary, nice benefits, lots of great minds to learn from, good work-life balance
cons: too much politics. Not much innovation.

headline: Great Training
pros: lots of great people that work for this company.
cons: same problems all large corporations have

headline: Engineer
pros: Intelligent peers, company encourages cycling (showers at different locations)
cons: Company doesn't want to invest in research, wants to take a lego approach to processor design.

headline: Great company
pros: young engineers and nice work atmosphere
cons: a bit far from Munich

headline: Great learning experience
pros: Nice place to work,Good manager,Good tech work,Good benefits,
cons: Lots of overhead staff in support.Closed Mobile and wireless.Attrition seems high. Not as good as was 3-4 years back

headline: Great place to work for
pros: Work/life balance. Great management. Senior mgmt take good care of teh employees - Training, oppurtunities
cons: Takes a long time to see career growth for new employees.

headline: Treated like crap at the end but good while it lasted
pros:
Good pay and benefits for more senior positions.
Good people at the staff level.
Good functional managers.
Small teams feels like smaller company.
cons:
Don't work for a remote design center -- first to get axed.
Total lack of cooperation across business units. 
Sales people running a technology company ... not a good idea.

headline: Training Institute, low pay, but good experience
pros:
Lots of experience from experienced people.
Lots of opportunity to move from one aspect of the IC process to another.
Some good managers.
cons:
Low pay.
Poor computing power.  Simulations take a long time.  
some bad managers.

headline: System Engineer
pros: Opportunity of learning new skills and doing your own projects. The company is giving best facilities especially to engineers . Good markets experiences learned.
cons: You have to build good relationships with customers, they may let to to solve tons of problems. Be able to work with them and be able to explain things well to them.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Very flexible and nice management
cons: Very frequent reorganization and layoutt

headline: Great Company with Great Opportunities
pros: Great people to work with, excellent learning opportunity, professional work culture and ethics, respect for every employee. Marker leader.
cons: Sometimes there can be high work pressure during the project. This is normal for any big companies and is more of an opportunity than a negative.

headline: I work as a software architect tasked with building next generation data analysis tools
pros: Great atmostphere to explore and learn. And if you get a good manager, the company is extremely condusive to building great products.
cons: Not all teams have the best managers in TI, just as in most companies.

headline: Typical Semiconductor Company
pros: Good learning ground in managing expectations and time management for priorities
cons: Always playing the catch up game with other faster and more innovative companies.

headline: Marketing
pros: Learn Lots of new thing and interworking
cons: Strategy Keep changing and no future goal

headline: Good place to work with some trade offs
pros: Benefits, profit sharing, culture, family value orient company
cons: Long hours, continual shift in management almost making you have to prove your worth as if you were new all over again.

headline: Great Company, Bad HR
pros: A lot to learn and do.
cons: Performance reviews are horrible and management only care about their own careers.

headline: Great hardware, not-so-good software
pros: Great place for hardware engineers, silicon designers, especially those skilled in analog. Good compensation and benefits package. Great people to work with. Flexible working hours for engineers.
cons: Software engineering is underdeveloped discipline. The mindset is that hardware can sell itself. Software serves to just demo hardware.

headline: TI
pros: Strongly believes in training.  A great place to learn.  Wonderful place to go right out of college and learn the ropes.
cons: Pay can be low and upward mobility is very limited.  They also have layoffs pretty regularly

headline: Demanding and Expecting
pros: Good in working environment and benefit wise, even with a sports complex.
cons:
Demanding (certain Dept.) that causes stress.
High expectations, strict managers and loads of task that employees hardly utilize the sports complex.
Hardly achive balance between work and life, some employees even stay in the office/plants for more than 12 hours.

headline: A learning , fulfilling work experience at TI
pros:
- Technically brilliant people. 
- Learning culture. 
- Good team work and product focus  within teams and across site
cons: - Shrinking opportunities in digital design

headline: Great company, with some very smart people.
pros:
- Good technical leadership.
- Good challenging work, with lot to learn especially at the beginning of your career.
- Not worked long enough to comment on the growth, but seems good to me.
cons:
- Considering it is a big organization, it may not be easy to go up the ladder.
Otherwise completely satisfied working here.

headline: An American tech giant crumbling in the hands of sales-heavy executives.
pros: Low cost of living in Dallas. Work-life balance. Flexible hours.
cons: TI's business principle is to avoid competition. If it's already late in a market, it is happy to stay out and never join the party. If it is already in but others start showing up, it happily drops the ball, drives the business to the ground and leaves it all behind. Basically, TI chooses not to compete (let's not get into why). This mode of operation is most disturbing for the technically talented. You might be very good at what you do and strive to stay on top of your trade, but you know that it is only a matter of time before TI will leave your area, selling out entire businesses or shutting them down. It is not a question of if, but a question of when. Most recent victims are a bunch of digital businesses.

headline: Fast paced interactive environment with a diverse working culture.
pros: The people are fantastic.  The management rewards outstanding work and promotes learning new software and provides challenges to those who want them.
cons: Continual re-organizational activities lead to decreased morale.

headline: Great learning experience for young engineers
pros: Worked here for 7 yrs. Great environment and professionally run company. Learnt a lot during my stint.
cons: Very conservative management. Prospects of growing in job is low. Also becoming more of an Analog company resulting in exit of lot of talented people.

headline: Good benefits.
pros: Open door policy with management.
cons: Difficult to advance while working as a machine operator.

headline: Great place to work, but high stress
pros: Challenges, working with top notch talent, great initiatives, energetic management.  Great place to grow and get a great technical and business exposure.
cons: Tight deadlines, overwhelming amount of work, long hours.  High pressure to always do things better.

headline: Good for money, not so good for technical challenge
pros: Good compensation and good benefits.
cons: You need to work on solving politics before solving technical issues.

headline: Good for money, not so good for technical challenge
pros: Good compensation and good benefits.
cons: You need to work on solving politics before solving technical issues.

headline: It's a great place to work.
pros: good work-life balance and good benefits
cons: no growth and lack of promotions

headline: Good company to work with in Analog and Embedded processing
pros: Texas Instruments India provides and excellent work culture where the folks around you are supporting and managers take good care. The work culture fuels innovation in you and helps grow in the organization. Technical contribution is seen very positively.
cons: Sometimes i feel that Texas Instruments India has lots of unnecessary managers and reporting structure becomes very hierarchical.

headline: Not a decent place to work anymore
pros:
Flexible working hour
Nice and friendly coworkers
Used to be a good technical company, focus and reward technical development, 10 years ago.
cons:
Too many reorgs, top managements are changing mind daily.
Not rewarding talent nor contribution, cut people like throwing away old shoes, sucks.
Quality is no longer a concern to this company, how to finish thing in a cheaper way is more important nowadays.

headline: Just started, but so far so great!
pros:
- Friendly, helpful managers, staff, and personnel. I felt like I was at home on my first day!
- Well organized, helpful orientation and new-hire process for new college hires
- Very helpful software systems to get up to date in a hurry
- Very "laid-back" atmosphere; can get on schedule on my own terms
- Casual dress!!
cons: - Was difficult in my particular job sometimes to get up-to-date on the software and commands associated with the job because I was the only one to start this month and kind of fell between the cracks as far as orientation for new engineers goes. But they still made the best of it!

headline: amazing place to work! Huge learning curve, inspiring culture!
pros: Amazingly ingenious people work here. Good pay and great life balance.  Wish i was still there!
cons: Huge company, sometimes gets lost in shuffle. No upwards mobility depending on position you are in.

headline: Upper Management Out of Touch
pros: They are good to their employees.  Great pay.  Great co-workers.
cons: Upper Management style is to re-org or layoff.  After a major layoff I went through 2 re-orgs a year for two years then was finally let go myself.  A year later they had yet another layoff and re-org.

headline: Product Marketing - Texas Instruments
pros:
Fast moving company
Good compensation
International environment
cons:
Low investment and short Term strategy
Multiple hierarchy layers
Overwhelming reporting

headline: Good company to work with!!!
pros:
1. Good , friendly environment
2. Freedom to work on your interest 
3. Good pay
cons: 1. depends on which team/group you go..

headline: Most ethical, challenging place to work
pros:
work with best brains of industry
decent pay package
Challenging work
cons:
Closing down most of businesses
cafetaria & break rooms

headline: No loyalty
pros: Great profit sharing plan.
cons: Remote design center?  Beware. Revenue drives your continued employment. Don't expect any loyalty from upper-management.

headline: Company Review
pros:
Get to learn lots of things.
Very Innovative Company , nice work culture..
Sometimes hectic.
Nice benefits.
cons:
No Transparency with upper management.
No proper Roadmap in terms of products.

headline: OK
pros: Good people and good culture.
cons: Recently shrinking to analog company.

headline: Great company. Uncertain future.
pros: Great coworkers. Great opportunities to move around to find the perfect job. Good pay. Flexible time. Interesting and challenging job.
cons: Lack of vision of the future by the leaders at the top. Focus is short term to please Wall Street. Buy back stock instead of investing in the future, in RandD. The competition is cheap so got to innovate. Politics are a big problem at all levels of management.

headline: Product and Test Engineering Review
pros:
1.  Technical knowledge among coworkers is there, tap into it on your own
2.  Size of company lends to opportunities to move within organizations
3.  Internal diversity organizations to build your personal network
4.  Diverse roles and expectations per PE/TE depending on your group
cons: Advancement and opportunities are more dependent on your timing (joining the group), mentorship (find one), your soft skills (like-ability, communications, appearance) and your internal management's capability to advocate your skills, rather than your technical skills and work ethic alone. It's a very inaccurate expectation to think that performance and hard work alone pays off in any corporate culture. This is not a TI specific "con" its a hard lesson for all employees of any larger corporations.

headline: Larg company with intuziasm of strartup
pros:
Dinamic company with a lot of opportunities. Multipul sites sprede over the golbe create opportunities for rlocation.
Texas Instruments has efficiant opiration.
cons:
Texas instruments has a a culture of long working days.
Reacently Texas instruments made a lot of changes in the focues of the company.

headline: (Was) One of great places to work
pros:
Fantastic work. 
Great work culture.
Good pay.
Really good middle management.
cons: Several re-orgs in the past few years disturbing the environment

headline: My experience at TI was great.
pros: Great benefits and great co-workers.
cons: I have no complaints about the company

headline: You learn a lot, but it's difficult to move up in software unless you know someone.
pros: GREAT atmosphere.  Hours aren't too taxing.  If you work on MCU/MPU, most of your work is actually pretty fun.  Your co-workers are usually your age and you end up making a lot of friends.
cons: Cafeteria isn't that great.  Tends to be a lot of layoffs in the MCU/MPU departments.  Difficult to move up.

headline: Great vision for strong company
pros: People, salary is decent, work is generally engaging
cons: Growth opportunities for some are limited by diversity ceiling

headline: Good company
pros: Great staff and people.  Interesting projects to work on.
cons: No work life balance at all.  While projects are interesting there are too many at a time.

headline: Good salary. Management sucks! No direction in company strategy.
pros:
Great pay and benefits.
Reasonable work life balance.
Co-workers are nice.
cons: Management heavy. High attrition rate. Too many lay offs. Management has no direction and unsure of their own decisions. Management does not want to compete but magically wants "high margins" and "new markets". Full of marketing and sales people at the top with complete lack of a clear technology vision. Sometimes it even feels like it's NOT a tech company!

headline: Not the Place for Older Employees
pros:
- Good compensation and benefits
- Good senior level leadership
cons:
- Company prefers to develop and promote younger employees
- Employees outside of headquarters have little opportunity for advancement
- Business units operate in functional silos

headline: Great company to work with. They care for their people.
pros: Good work. Work life balance. Top talents around to work with.
cons: Career Growth slow. Once you learn the work it is mostly about execution.

headline: Program Management
pros: Work-Life Balance, leading technology company, very knowledgable people, competitive compensation.
cons: Limited growth opportunities but that's location dependent. To grow and be at senior management level it's almost a requirement to move to Dallas eventually - the head office.

headline: Great people, horrible management
pros: Passionate employees.  Great product. Great customers
cons: Management does not listen to employees regarding market trends. They create products that compete with each other.  Micro managers.

headline: Great
pros: Good atmosphere, good lunches, and everything.
cons: I don't really have any.

headline: Lots of hard work surrounded by quality individuals
pros: Smart, hard people with an innovative spirit that will do what is needed to get their work done
cons: Minimal room for career advancement in specific area of the company, not necessarily the case company wide

headline: marcom
pros: good colleagues, good environment, good hardware
cons: office politics, cross BU coordination is bad, etc

headline: A large company with its own ups and downs
pros: Management keep trying to put focus on earnings and financial health of the company
cons: Less attention on retention of talent that will eventually hurt growth.

headline: A large company with its own ups and downs
pros: Management keep trying to put focus on earnings and financial health of the company
cons: Less attention on retention of talent that will eventually hurt growth.

headline: Expects engineers to work weekends for extended periods of time
pros: Resources are well organized.  Great access to tools and ability to deliver small products in very high volume
cons: Technically, products are not very leading edge - just quick to deliver at the expense of burning out its staff.  Products can be designed by engineers with 1-2 years of experience; so, they use a log of young engineers who are very energetic (at least for a while).

headline: good
pros: good work, god job good salary
cons: management is very very fickle.

headline: Excellent work but with a roller coaster career track
pros:
The quality of work is outstanding in the industry. You never work here, because you will most likely have a chance to do what you like for extended periods of time. When you enjoy what you do, you won't get tired of working.
Work life balance options are unparalleled in the industry!
Good for starters and those who have given up on career ambition but like to settle with a monotonic career at the bag end of life.
No peer feedback, so one gets to make good friends with peers.
Great learning opportunities.
cons:
Ultimate path to career termination or career suicide.
Hikes without rhyme or reason or logic or math.
Bureaucracy is outstanding in the industry.
Workload increases in proportion to pay hike for those who are not on management ladder.. alternatively if one gets pay hike of 20%, one is likely to work for atleast 10% more time, to keep the job.

headline: Engineer
pros: Their paychecks won't bounce. Profit Sharing is offered. You could get advancement if you jump high enough. Templeton stopped saying "agh" 250 times during his updates.
cons: Each business unit treats other business within TI units like a competitor. Management has effectively created this.  If you get a design win it was luck...If you lose a socket it was your fault. Useful training is absolutely impossible to obtain. The whole peer/mentor system has shut-down. No one has time to train you, they are too busy trying to get their projects moving along. Management will show up and schedule you for a meeting and ask "So, what have you been doing". Management will release proclamations to save money and basically cut off all tools you used to use and implement new ones. Then give you no time to learn the new tools but your project better not suffer. Kind of like, you shall make bricks without straw. Oh my gosh...I realized I am starting to hate it there. How in the hell did they get on the list for one of the happiest places to work? All I see are miserable people. Except for the ones always dishing out the work. They seem happy they don't have to shovel. Also, someone has stolen my laptop. I left to get coffee, came back and it was gone. Thanks.

headline: A growing experience for me personally.
pros: A good place to learn and opportunity to get to work with very smart people.
cons: Mobility, bureaucracy may be an issue as in any big corporation.

headline: Good overall experience so far. Don't know what the future holds though.
pros:
- Very supportive management in terms of career development
- Flexible work schedule
- Projects with good visibility
- Great learning opportunity
- Open door policy
cons:
- Too many layoffs effecting job security
- Upper management seems to be reserved for Marketing/Sales folks

headline: As of Quality  and Product Engineer
pros: Open for new concepts development and implementation as far as ROI is demonstrated
cons: Strategy seems to be defined based on Lowest risk management

headline: excellent
pros: good work environment, flexible hours, decent benifit
cons: too many layoff, management changes startegy frequenty

headline: Very good place to work, in my experience.
pros: Intelligent coworkers and reasonable management.
cons: A tendency to downsize. There have been multiple layoffs since I've been with the company, but I attribute that more to the economic trends than anything else.

headline: Supporting manager and highly motivated team.
pros:
Overall this is a good company to work. Team are very talented, and you will love to be working in this environment. I personally have a good manager who shields us from all the politics which goes on at the higher management level. 

Work is rewarding and salaries are I believe competitive with industry. It has a good brand name and other companies respect employees working here.
cons:
1. Bad office politics at senior level.
2. Employee performance review system is not very objective and depends on votes from whole lot of other manages who do not even know your work.
3. Arbitrary decisions at senior management level impacting productivity of employees (changing design tools, shifting focus too often, too much changes in management etc)
4. Not too impressed with sudden closing of large business lines just because there is too much competition or margins are low (still profitable). I believe this may impact long term where the company may not have the required IP to get into new strategic business.

headline: Graphic designer ( photoshop & coreldraw )
pros:
- I worked at Siemens international company agent full-time for 1 year.
- I worked at Earthlink telecommunications  full-time for 2 year.
- I worked at Almalek telecommunications  full-time for more than 1 year.
- I worked at 101egypt Advertising  full-time for more than 1 year.
cons: This was a great companies to work for.

headline: Great Learning Experince
pros: Talented People Around. Middle management is very approachable and understands hands-on issues. Good career grooming.
cons: Average Salaries. No Stock Options at lower job grades. Technical vision on digital side is very short sighted.

headline: Gained a lot of experience working with very talented people

headline: Analog/Mixed Signal Layout Engineer

headline: Finance MBA Co-op

You need to be very flexible as goals, obejctives, priorities, management, teams, organization are changing quite rapidly.TI provide great training and look first for potential and can help you develop your skills.
cons: Very challenging environment with tough deadlines, a lot of fire work, tough objectives. It can burn you out and consume you entirely.

cons: Too much work pressure. You'll be kept on your toes almost always. Moreover, you'll be pitted against your co-workers and continuously compared with them.

As your career grows, your chances of being layed-off
do also.

headline: antiquated
pros: learn a lot, different jobs,good, hardworking people

headline: Wonderful journey @ TI
pros: Provide lot of opportunities to explore the individual interests. Great supervisors always help at any given time to learn new technologies
cons: Lack of vision with SLT and not aggressive in investments. Do not stick to their roadmaps and frequent org changes.

headline: Graphic Designer/Illustrator
pros: The people are great to work with, innovative, progressive, cutting edge.

headline: A great company to work for
pros: Open culture. Encourages discussion, out of box experiments, taking on different/additional responsibilities to grow as an individual and pick up additional career skills.
cons: I really have not found a 'con' in a typical sense yet in my association with the company. It's a good place to work for.

Bad management sometimes in deciding for the future. Too many deadlines for the amount of 
work hours and competitiveness compared to the market.
Benefits are not that great when compared to other places.

headline: TI used to be a balanced company, but now its culture is negative and depressing
pros: Financially stable, good reputation with customers

headline: Very good company to work for
pros: Good place to grow in your career

headline: Not a bad place to work, but can be a struggle to get ahead.
pros: The company is good about work/life balance. Everyone seems to be treated fairly.  While people make the usual complaints about management, I have found it to be a little better than other places I've worked.
cons:
Managers will tell you they "pay for performance," but in reality the same top dogs always get the good raises. TI uses an odd performance evaluation formula.  Employees are ranked against each other. The top 10% get the bulk of the raises, the bottom 10% get nothing and are put on administrative counseling, the remaining 80% splits the remaining budget.  Sound reasonable until you realize, in a department full of awesome, outstanding technicians, someone is still in the bottom 10%.

Positions in management require a bachelor degree.  Many managers are engineers who have no people skills.

headline: Poor respect for employees
pros: Great opportunity to learn.
cons: When change in workplace occurs, company will discharge employees without notice.

headline: Good company with lots of opportunities/ market leader
pros: company has very good and competent employees. The management is also good. Steady work positions and interesting challenges in the focus areas.
cons: Big company with its own bureaucracy. Some constant changes in process/ change in focus areas. The prospects for experienced folks starts decreasing in many areas.

headline: Overall, my experience was wonderful
pros: Interesting and exciting work atmosphere
cons: Heavy workload and a lot is expected

headline: Lots of opportunity
pros: I have heard that TI stood from tiny income, but I didn't find that to be the case.  Admittedly with such a large company there are jobs that have no future and room for growth, but once you work at TI you can move to other jobs.  Conversely there are jobs at TI that are rewarded substantially in base income, bonuses, and other benefits.  If you are able to get into one of the high revenue group and are successful, compensation is very good.
cons: Electrical design engineering is the central task at TI and if you aren't in design, analog circuit design in particular, it's more difficult to get recognized in the technical community.

headline: An employee friendly company. Cares for overall development. Produced many successful start ups.
pros: TI is the first MNC in India to setup operations under STP in Semiconductor sector in 1985. TI Bangalore R&D center has been growing cautiously but Sales & Marketing centers are opening up in many cities and growing rather briskly. The best Analog and Mixed Signal R & D company in India. The Bangalore center touches all key Business Units of TI Inc.
cons: The Wireless BU has undergone a roadmap change last year which resulted in a major layoff. However the TI management helped to place most engineers within other BUs or elsewhere. The volatility of the market reflects almost immediately.

headline: Great company to work for

cons: salary is not competitive compared to industry, work-life balance can get really bad at the final phase of projects, micro-management

headline: Good start

headline: Spent three years at TI coming out of college. Great experience, very smart people working there.
pros: Huge company with all types of opportunities. From Marketing all the way to hardcore engineering.

headline: Wonderful company. Worked their 6 years.
pros: Excellent people and work environment.
cons: Semiconductor industry as a whole is more cyclical than most fields. So lay offs are common. But TI goes out of their way to keep their people.

headline: Excellent place to work and grow
pros: Innovative, Inspiring, Rich Templeton is doing an awesome job!
cons: If your Senior Manager leaves, the replacement may bring in his own team leaving you out!

headline: TI is one of the best technology companies to work for in the Dallas area.
pros: With its diverse business groups and broad product lines, TI offers the opportunity to be involved in any area of the electronics industry. Great benefits are provided with an opportunity to participate in the success of the company.
cons: Conservative company with limited appetite for risk.

headline: Not a bad place to work
pros: Good place to grow your technical skills, especially if you are in embedded software domain. To make the best use of the position, one might have to go and do projects over and beyond his routine defect fixes though. There is freedom and opportunities to learn. If you have not worked in any other big silicon company, there is a good chance that you'll love this company. The moment you know what is out there, things might look different.
cons: Lot of mismanagement, micromanagement. Many managers regurgitate what they hear from engineers under them. This makes you needing to do a lot of advertising oneself to climb the ladder, also get to be some manager's personal favorite. That's what helps. Very few cares about how technically capable you are.

headline: Lots of opportunity
pros: Easy to transfer into department you like if your good. Pay and benefits are competitive.
cons: Too much focus on process. Management can be petty sometimes.

headline: I have worked at TI for over 27 years including various sales positions, various management roles and corporate product
pros: A trusted supplier to top OEM’s with a strong history of delivering globally, a wide breadth of products in very high volume.
cons: Despite declining revenue the corporate strategy, “execute and gain share”, is a clear depiction of just how out of touch top management has become clinging to an excel-like, bottom line philosophy - simply embarrassing.  Forcing a playbook - do as I say - strategy  in place of pride and innovation has alienated the vast majority of the mostly engineering company.

headline: Learn a lot.
pros: You will know the latest information about analog device and you could learn a lot of technical knowledge from internal resource.
cons: There are a lot of works that will come to you at the same time and you need to finish it by yourself. If you could not work smart, you will spend a lot of time on the job.

headline: Great career growth
pros: Unlimited opportunities. Each individual employee can end up to a better position if they strive hard to get where they want
cons: Work-Life Balance. Generally, the factory load requirement is above the capacity. To cope up with demand, employees need to work extra hours. Need to balance work and family life

headline: Its just a job not a career
pros: the pay is competitive and flexible work schedule and work from home schedule

the security controls and officers are a little more intrusive than necessary one technician read all emails and management knew so they avoided emails
employees call pretended to be headhunters to try and discover your salary and then it travels quickly
my relocation realtor told someone of all the neighborhoods I looked at and it travelled through the building

headline: planner

headline: Great Company
pros: Good benefits, good growth potential, great leadership
cons: I cannot think of anything negative in my tenure here so far

headline: great company to work for if you can keep your job
pros: great work culture and work environment. Great coworkers but sometimes the supervisors are not very friendly.
cons: The problem is that layoffs occurs quite frequently. And if you're not lucky, you'll be out of job.

headline: Overall good company with some good ideas, but some poor managers
pros:
Great benefits
Some good ideas
Diverse product portfolio
Very fair work/life balance for the most part
cons:
Some clearly misguided market attempts
Some managers clearly rose through the ranks through brown-nosing and not competence
Training can be harder to come by than in similar companies
Can be a bit stodgy when it comes to seizing new markets and innovation

headline: Healthy environment for young to middle experienced
pros: Lots of career options and growth.  Good benefits and diversity.
cons: Senior management can be remote

headline: Great experience, amazing people, great work-life balance
pros: You get to work on great technology projects with amazingly talented people. You get to learn a lot and explore the field of electronics.
cons:
While there's a lot of flexibility in terms of choosing your expertise, it's very difficult to move through verticals.
Also, there's this communication gap between business managers and subordinates due to which the latter are not able to relate their work to the bigger business strategy.

headline: Great place to learn, but environment is changing.
pros: Competitive pay and benefits, good work life balance, great and very intelligent teams.
cons: New direction seems to be towards commodities - both in products and in people.  Lack of commitment to talent development outside of EE design teams.

headline: Challenging work, keeps your skills current
pros:
- Always have challenging work. You won't become a dinosaur working here. 
- I've never heard of a more humane company when it comes to family emergencies or personal issues (assuming you don't have a history of abusing their trust) such as death in the family, hospital leave, etc.
- You will work with the smartest, gentlest people and will love going to work. There is a strong emphasis on teamwork and egalitarianism. They must intentionally look for collaborators because there are very few bullies or uber-negative competitive types. If you're type A personality but also ethical and respectful, you'll fit right in. 
- True flex time. Work overtime when its needed and take off when it isn't. No one cares when you arrive and when you leave as long as you perform above a certain level. (You have to earn the privilege first, so not many people abuse the system.) This is the first place I've ever worked where I wasn't frustrated by deadbeats. 
- Truly collaborative. The web team doesn't one-up each other. Everyone is hired for a specific talent, and is expected to exchange ideas and help each other. If I don't know how to code a particular feature, I can literally go ask around and people are excited to pitch in. (The web is so splintered, there are a lot of processes, and we change things so quickly that this is really critical. No one can make it alone in this game anymore!)
cons: - Onramping is difficult. Things change quickly and we're interdependent. Just chill for the first year and half -- all your colleagues went through this too. Do not expect to be 100% independent as quickly as you would be elsewhere. No one will blame you. Its just part of working for a fast-paced, global company.

headline: Was acquired in the National Semiconductor purchase
pros: Good benefits.  Worked in a Design Center and the people were great. Worked in R&D and was very well supported in new equipment and/or technologies for use in development work.
cons: Project decisions are often made with short minded goals.  Drive for immediate return on R&D investment does not allow time for the R&D teams to properly meet design goals, corners get cut.

headline: Good Place to cut your teeth...
pros: Excellent training program for student hires, promotional opportunities in early years, competitive pay, opportunities for meaty jobs very quickly
cons: No real value placed on experience, promotions based on potential as opposed to actual results

headline: TSE Rotation Program--Prepares New College Grads to Face Engineering Challenges in a Customer-Facing Role
pros: Exposure to a field sales office to begin the program provides an exciting overview of what a technical sales role entails. The product marketing and business operations rotations that follow are filled with challenging, impactful work that allow TSEs to contribute to the sales and marketing teams while also building a TI network to be leveraged in the future. The quick 1-3 month rotations also mirror the fast-paced environment one can expect when entering into a sales or marketing role.
cons: None! The TSE program is a real investment on TI's part in terms of the time and resources it provides for its technical sales engineers.

headline: As a new grad, the environment at TI promotes open mentorship with emphasis in conducting business eithically.
pros:
-TSA program opens you to a large network of individuals within the company 
-High growth potential
-Understanding selling/marketing/supply chain
-System level knowledge of high tech applications
cons: Nothing. The TSA program is full of great benefits and opens up to a large range of opportunities in sales or marketing. There is a ramp up process for each step of this rotational program and there are a multitude of mentors that help you through.

headline: Good Company, Decent pay and benefits, always changing.
pros: Is a stable company with job security in certain departments
cons: Long hours sometimes, a lot of change which can cause a negative impact sometimes.

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Very professional people, good remuneration, opportunities to move WorldWide
cons: Sometimes management not close enough to their teams

headline: Amazing opportunity to develop engineering skills with TI's Product Engineering Rotation Program!
pros:
TI saw a need to develop Product Engineers quickly. To do so, they created something that crams years and years of experience into a concise two year program. I have the amazing opportunity to work with four completely separate groups that all tie back into my work as a product engineer. This type of exposure so early on in my career is the thing others dream about.

Additionally, TI has such a wide portfolio of parts that I am always able to satisfy my curiosity and desire to learn. I can dive deep and learn all about the device physics of a certain part, or I can go broad and learn all about a family of devices and how they operate. And when I get tired of those, I can repeat the process with other devices.
cons: The only thing that people might consider a "con" is the fact that this job REQUIRES you to move abroad for 6 months. However, I don't consider that a negative thing. In fact, that was one of the main selling points for this rotation program.

headline: Solid company to work for
pros: Pay and schedule were good
cons: Twelve hour Night work is hard

headline: TI
pros:
International and multi-cultural company 
Promoting individual performance
cons: Highly demanding for work-load vs projects milestones

headline: Focus on state-of-the-art
pros: Willing to put fort the effort to succeed in the current marketplace
cons: Sometimes lacks real top-drawer leadership and vision

headline: First Year Employee in the Product and Test Engineering Rotation Program
pros: I like working at Ti because it is a highly technical company offering extremely competitive compensation. This rotation program allows me to learn about the Product and Test role while also contributing to a team. Not only does this role incorporate Fabrication and Design, but Ti is also paying for me to work overseas and learn about the Assembly of integrated circuits.
cons: The only con that I see is the rotations are only for six months. I see this as a con because once I start to become confident and proficient, I switched rotations and start learning at a new position.

headline: Freindly, valueable, and exciting experience at TI's Application's Rotation Program!
pros: Ti has a great employee community, everyone here is friendly, helpful, and willing to teach! The rotational program that I entered though put me in a group of other recent graduates and I was pretty much forced to make friends in Dallas, the program has been an amazing launchpad for my career! Ti also treats it's employees very well, good benefits and compensation, and many opportunities to share in the sucess of the company, they really make the employees feel valuable.
cons: I have nothing to say in the cons section of the company, so far this job has been everything I imagined and more.

headline: Great engineering company, all the benefits (and drawbacks) of a large company.
pros: Strong support for extended education and career development.  Diversity of products allows for a lot of lateral movement between organizations.  This makes for a great place for a young engineer to gain experience fast.
cons: Political issues common to most large companies prevent advancement in some organizations beyond lower management levels.  Large scale periodic RIF reduce long term prospects of some positions as directed by market analysts which may not reflect actual business opportunities.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Lean structure; flattish management structure, engineering environment, and ethical company
cons: Company decided to shed the OMAP business, and that will hurt in that the company will NOT stay at the forefront of digital & process technology

headline: Decent company to work for
pros: Benefits are good, pay is decent
cons: Management is disconnected; technology is poor

headline: Technical work very interesting but many fiefdoms
pros: You have the opportunity to grow.  They tend to hire many right out of college and give you quite a bit of responsibility.  Do your due diligence.  Talk to current employees.  There are many around that can give good insight into various departments.
cons: Not quite sink or swim but they are looking for self-starters.  They tend to juggle departments around with frequency.  This gives them the excuse to downsize.  They will overwork you if you let them.  Some departments are quite disfunctional.

headline: Work life balance
pros: Here you will easily get work life balance, with flexible work timing and with extra curriculum  like sports, yoga, dance, gym inside office premises itself
cons: Sometime you will bit poor management during your work life in office

headline: Best company to work for - Innovation, Technology, People - everything is highly valued
pros:
State of the art products
Wide product portfolio
Very good compensation
Strong player in the market against competition
Flexi work hours
Friendly and open culture
Employer and employees are highly valued within the company and by the market
Challenging and variety of products / portfolio to work with
