headline: Manufacturing Supervisor/Specialist in the Semiconductor Fab..
pros: Very Very good Place to work, I worked there for 30 Years...
cons: Force Retired. Worded in DFab,Dose5

headline: I enjoyed working for the company but you had a real bad drinker for a manager and we didn't see eye to eye that was why
pros: TI is a very good company to work for I worked for the for 23 years I the past and enjoyed it
cons: The managers need to listen to the worker bees at times they have good ideals.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: great life and work balence
cons: Too much politics.. management does like experience people anymore.. very analog focused company and too many layoffs

headline: Large Company with Varied Culture and Values
pros: Some departments are very casual and flexible, and provide good work-life balance.
cons: Some departments are very formal and rigid, and do not provide a good work-life balance.

headline: Enjoyable
pros:
I was given wide latitude to find and fix problems, and received recognition in the Corporate Citizenship Report.  Our group was like a family that was spread across the world.
Great benefits and Profit Sharing.  Company is dedicated to humanitarian projects in all countries in which it does business.  Employees are encouraged to volunteer, and are allowed time during work hours to do so.  Civic involvement is encouraged.
cons: Like all large companies, sometimes the structure impedes progress and adds costs.  A (very) few in department-level HR are not always willing to address issues.

headline: Traditional, but stable and ethical company. Great place for long-term career types; harder for dreamers
pros: An American company with manufacturing in America! Almost unheard of these days. Stable, ethical, and with a CEO that's sane, competent, and fairly compensated. Plus it's good work.
cons: Easy to get stuck in place. Movement within TI is slow, particularly if you're not within a design group.

headline: General about company
pros: Good place to work in general...
cons: Politics involved unnecessarily for many cases..

headline: Great company. Great values.
pros: TI is an older company with great values but still has the expertise to be a great competitive technology company. TI is a huge company and has a foot in many areas, so there are good opportunities.
cons: Upper management can be pretty flaky depending on the department. TI being an older company means an older style of management a lot of the time, so you get a lot of top-down directives that don't make much sense.

headline: Generic
pros: Overall good place to work, friendly people, professional atmosphere. Good amenities for the employees like a company cafeteria. Good IT system.
cons: Very old facilities and equipment - a lot of unexpected repairs. Non-critical issues are not addressed promptly, i.e. flooring, and heating/cooling issues for the office areas.

headline: DSP FA Section Manager
pros: Leading edge technology, well diversified,  lots of career opportunity and always supporting of higher education, competitive salary
cons: Heavy work load (over 50 hours a week is typical).

headline: Adapting to a change: 3 careers at TI
pros: Great people and great career
cons: Working in a 24/7 manufacturing environment.

headline: d
pros: Balanced life, Work culture, Work load, People/co-workers, blah-blah
cons: Career development, conservative investment, blah-blah

headline: Very good
pros: it is enriching analog design and silicon debug
cons: Too much of work also

headline: My Experience worked all Industrial Producting Engineering Work.
pros: My sciope of Work Responsibilities : Process Industrial Plant Engineering.
cons:
I have not employee by Texas Instruments, diffrential Industrial Process Instruments Trans-
mitters.

headline: Challenging and rewarding
pros: Rewards performance, provides large latitude in decision making, allows differences of opinions. Appreciation of the fact that we work in an ambiguous market environment, so it is not possible to play by a standard set of rules.
cons: Very tactical day-today management by senior management, high pressure work environment, low tolerance for people seeking "9-5" job.

headline: work at ti
pros: challenging, exciting, learn a lot, fun
cons: mainly analog field dominated company

headline: Challenging/ Rewarding Internship experience
pros: Dynamic work environment, Challenging, plenty of support from the surrounding engineers who have knowledge and experience and are willing to share. Very rewarding experience once solution to problem is found
cons: Can be some long hours if you are not careful. Also, plenty of work to be done, never seems to end

headline: Challenging/ Rewarding Internship experience
pros: Dynamic work environment, Challenging, plenty of support from the surrounding engineers who have knowledge and experience and are willing to share. Very rewarding experience once solution to problem is found
cons: Can be some long hours if you are not careful. Also, plenty of work to be done, never seems to end

headline: Good place to start your carrer in India
pros:
* Oppurtunity to work across different domain
* Good work place enivornment
cons: * Sometimes they do over engineering in projects

headline: Fairly good experience over 8 years in different areas at TI
pros: OK compensation if you are not a designer. I am an EE, but was not a designer. TI tends to fix problems promptly in comparison to other companies where I have worked. Their Ethics department is not a sham. I had to use it once in the 8 years I was there and there was no retaliation, but the problem was brought to top management.
cons: There was a regular lay-off train. At one point a manager friend of mine there said she had laid off all the "bottom 10%" and they told her to choose another (two successive layoffs.) She said everyone there was top-notch. The told her to find the one who was bottom 10% of the talent in her group anyway. TI laid off some really good people while some bad ones stayed.

headline: analog design engineer
pros: nice place to work. Good responsibility
cons: Sometimes work life balance is affected

headline: Good job,
pros: Excellent pay for performance. Hardwork is rewarded and there are lots of opportunities
cons: little benefit work-life balance. Not much value for experience

headline: Good company but slow to change
pros:
Growth within the company / department
Big name in the industry
cons:
Management is decided on seniority not skill
Little to no recognition

headline: Excellent place to explore technical career with huge learning opportunity
pros: stable work environment, generally lots of freedom to explore and do more than required of the job
cons: vertical growth limited in India specifically due to the nature of the business in India. This could though change in the future as the site grows in significance both in the region and globally.

headline: Great company! Family friendly!
pros: Profit sharing, travel experience, opportunity to work at Fortune 100 company, lots of opportunities to make a difference.
cons: Lots of layoffs, quick to do re-organization of teams

headline: Great Company
pros: Great company as it knows its market, not avoiding tough decision when they need to be made, great sales force, great product and operation overall, great people culture
cons: not enough innovation. Easy in giving up when products are facing competition

headline: Great atmosphere at a top company!
pros: Great talent.  Good pay and benefits.  Excellent work/life balance.  Top notch management.
cons: Something is missing to keep this company from truly breaking out and winning the market share that is desired.  I wouldn't expect the company to experience huge growth, but it is has terrific financials.  Not afraid to reorganize and cut jobs in the process.

headline: Bad managers. Epitome of "Good ol boys network" and very rednecky
pros: none that i can think of. new hire program was ok. very little advancement opportunities
cons: Title says it all. boring role. bad managers. bad pay. bad vacation package

headline: It was a very fulfilling experience at TI, I was able to learn as much as I could absorb everyday.
pros: It was exciting to work with cutting edge technology along with some of the sharpest and brightest people I have ever worked with; and I have been in electronics over 30 years.
cons: I did not always agree with some of the policies and actions regarding foreign investments while working at Texas Instruments.

headline: Heavy middle management, good culture, more reactive to market than cutting-edge.
pros: Great work-life balance; smart and friendly colleagues. Because plans are not tightly roadmapped, lots of free range to be creative.
cons: Slow career advancement. Lots of breaucrats in middle management, who spin and don't have great roadmaps for tackling market conditions. Reactive to market, not proactive.

headline: Overall a good company
pros: Good technical work, fair treatment
cons: Failure to change plans into action, too quick to make changes

headline: An Old School Company
pros:
Exposure to latest technology trends - before they make the papers!  
International flavor - colleagues from all over the world. 
TI does care about its employees, for the most part. They will do the right thing, usually.  If there is a problem, it is usually not company policy, it is a rogue manager.   
Good benefits.
cons:
Insular culture - Top management is dominated by Texans. Although there are many managers and employees from all around the world, at the end of the day, it is a very Southern perspective that dominates. This means that if there is an Elephant in the Room, they will act like you are Rude for saying so. Or they will tell you to remove the elephant, but will not give you any resources to manage Elephant removal. 
 
If you're not an engineer, you don't matter.

Travel can be insane.

headline: Program Managment
pros: Solid company with large focus on growth
cons: Large digital system development is decreasing in priority

headline: Product Line
pros: Good pay, flexible hours, good opportunities for new grads
cons:
Lack of leadership, too much blame lower levels.
Lack of Strategic thinking and very little support to R&D and the technical community.

headline: Software development at a Silicon Company
pros: Great place to do embedded software, deep access to SoC internals to enable tight sw/hw integration and Multi-core sw development.
cons: Software is an enabler for hardware, constraining the level of sw abstraction

headline: Micromanaged
pros: Learned new processes and experimental methods.
cons: Managers were not leaders, very often did not know what you did.

headline: Good steady employment
pros: The company is solid and treats its employees quite well even when times are bad.  TI has been innovative and working on improving its standing in the industry.
cons: Some bad politics inside the company has held some innovators back from making contributions to a brighter, stronger company.

headline: Great company with many benefits
pros: Good working conditions, high tech great career starter
cons: moving production to overseas facilities with lower pay scales

headline: I join TI in the beginning of this year from my last job still as layout at Fairchild . not get used to the environment
pros: There got a lot training involved in every aspect.
cons: The avenue is getting worse

headline: Good environment and professional people
pros: Good profit sharing and personal growth
cons: Company seems to quit against competition instead of investing

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: great people, great environment, lots of challenges, great place for self development, good compensation
cons: little hectic, slow career growth, slight office politics

headline: It is a solid company with competitive salary
pros: Flexibility in your job role to get things done
cons: Lack of individual recognition and career opportunities

headline: Nice workers, interesting work, but brutal and incompetent management
pros: Lots of projects to work on, nice co-workers. If you are lucky with a technically competent supervisor, you will thrive. But planning for the long-term is difficult -- there are organizational changes (restructurizations) that happen more often than 6 months! Meaning that your position is in flux most of the time.
cons: management is non-engineering, often incompetent, but arrogant and brutal to defend their salary at your cost. Projects are not assigned based on technical skill but through internal process of managerial decision making. Since most managers are not technically skilled, projects are assigned and evaluated based on a political and other non-technical reasons. This creates very poor and subjective evaluation process.

headline: Fulfilling
pros: Ethical company, good recognition system
cons: "Real" decision making limited to VP level. Site/branch level act as if they are making decision and section level manages have given up even acting to be decision makers.

headline: Overall good experience.
pros: Good compensation, benefits, and opportunities.
cons: Manufacturing related management positions are 24/7/365 making it difficult to maintain work/life balance.

headline: Lots of potential to learn, company direction unclear.
pros: There are some great people to work with at TI.  It's has great ethics policies and behavior.  There are lots of potential areas to learn in.
cons: Lots of short-sighted off-shoring happened with people training their own replacements.

headline: My first job right out of college.
pros: This had a great and friendly job atmosphere with great perks.
cons: At the time, there came a massive lay-off.

headline: Great Company and great place to work
pros: Great work life balance, great value
cons: Not too many cons here

headline: It was a great company.
pros: The benefits are fair and upper management is supportive of employee development. There is also a huge emphasis on multi-culturalism. Overall, a great experience.
cons: Middle management likes to run operations on the cheap which means frequently being understaffed and incredibly slow to give raises. The money is there in the budget, but they like to keep a tight lid on salaries.

headline: Stimulating and rewarding work environment
pros: Exciting projects; cutting edge silicon process technology; commitment to innovation and design quality; driven by an ethical ethos; high degrees of upward mobility for talented young employees; "family" feel as an employee of the company.
cons: There seems to be a trend of consolidating remote design centers and pushing people towards working in Dallas, TX - it is hard to gain traction on the career ladder away from HQ. Some business units are inclined to leverage stale designs in the name of getting to market rather than pushing the envelope.

headline: Interesting with opportunities, but with challenges too!
pros: Opportunities, job safety, relaxed work atmosphere!
cons: Not much room to improve yourself

headline: Good place to develop skills early on in career, pays well, though very limited future options
pros:
- Good starting salary as compared with other semiconductor firms in India
- Good work experience in the beginning of career
cons:
- Very limited options for employee professional development 
- Doesn't encourage further education
- Non-existent internal job transfers inside TI, unlike other TI global locations. 

Note that above cons apply to only TI India Sales and Marketing, otherwise T.I. is a great place to work for.

headline: TIPI Baguio
pros: Very good company when it comes to health benefits and other perks.  The location of the company is also good since it is in Baguio City where it is not too warm. The products are good and interesting for technically inclined people
cons: The environment and the nature of the engineering jobs there are very very stressful especially if you are on the manufacturing side supporting everything. You feel overworked because you are really overworked. The HR department is pro management

headline: Very smart engineers, flexible environment, very good work-life balance
pros:
People are very nice and willing to teach you.
Very flexible environment.
Good incentives and reasonable perks.
Excellent work-life balance.
cons:
Lack of long term vision.
Lack of engineers at top management.
Image of a gigantic conservative company.

headline: Great place to work
pros: TI values employee retention and there are many opportunities within such a large company.  The pay is comparable to other companies in the industry.  TI also places value on work-life balance and offers many flexible options.
cons: Recent company performance has led to some downsizing and employee morale was affected.  Cost cutting has also affected some of the perks previously provided to employees.

headline: Education Technology Division
pros: Smart people, interesting products, lots of customer contact
cons: vision was not always clear and consistant

headline: Different promises from different people in HR....none kept
pros: Large company, decent benefits.  Lots of opportunity if you want to live in the Dallas area.
cons: Lack of trust in HR representatives.  Promises made but not kept.  If you are a part of an acquired company, start looking for other opportunities immediately.

headline: Different promises from different people in HR....none kept
pros: Large company, decent benefits.  Lots of opportunity if you want to live in the Dallas area.
cons: Lack of trust in HR representatives.  Promises made but not kept.  If you are a part of an acquired company, start looking for other opportunities immediately.

headline: Decent Experience
pros: Fair pay and benefits. tend to have products in growth areas so there is always something to learn or be excited about. Many travel opportunities.
cons: A lot of meetings. Seemingly drastic business decisions resulting in sale or termination of large groups. Consequently, it felt like a rather cutthroat environment. Slight image problem: most people don't know where what they produce besides calculators.

headline: Best Company to work so far!
pros: Texas Instruments is the best company to work for me, so far. Maybe I am fortunate to work with very smart and very humble people, who knows to appreciate your work, and also respect you at the highest level.
cons: Cannot say anything bad about Texas Instruments!

headline: An excellent first job for a young engineer
pros: Lots of smart employees to learn from, resources and benefits of a large company, steady job to pay off student loans and save money when in your youth, working in some interesting areas of the market and interacting with big and small customers, diverse workforce
cons: Old and conservative company, pay and raises could be better for younger employees, restrained by large size

headline: Excessive focus on cost
pros: Great people work here.  There is also some degree of flexibility on your schedule.  The benefits are generally good.  One nice perk is that if you are in a high enough job grade you can earn not only bonus but profit sharing as well.
cons: Resourcing is too tight, goals too broad.  If you could focus on a few things it would be tolerable, but you get stretched so thin.  Frequent re-orgs also mean that there's a lack of accountability.  And finally, no one can do anything that costs money (unless you are in sales, presumably).  It all leads to a very constrained environment with lots of little chiefs.

headline: Great work place
pros:
Good place to learn new development
Well organized work structure
cons:
Seniors over shadowing others
No similarity in terms of home rules among internal factories

headline: Texas Instruments is a great place to work
pros: Flexibilty of work timings, very supportive staff, great IT projects, team work, collaboration
cons: Travel may be needed for some jobs. Sometimes it can be hierarchial. Too much medhodology is applied for project management

headline: A good first job company
pros: Big company. Good health insurance. Do not need to dress up. A good place for a young engineer to start a career.
cons: Big company. Lack of innovative. Need at least a few corporate managers who are real engineers. Need to treat engineers better.

headline: One of largest chip maker work aggressive to gain market shares
pros: Great work environment, respect with each other,  result oriented
cons: Heavy work load, need work hard and smart to balance work and life

headline: A great place to work
pros:
Work culture is great - independence for making decisions and flexible timing
Hard work is appreciated by the team
The quality of work is very good
cons:
Work load gets high with smaller teams and multiple projects
Compensation offered is moderate (varies across teams)

headline: Was once a great company.....
pros: Can move around if position doesn't suite you.
cons: Contractors, contractors, contractors.  Over the past 6 years - more and more contractors fill departments.  If you've been there over 20 years, you have a target on your back.

headline: TI is a good company to work for
pros:

Everyone is professional

Employee recognition could be more consistent

headline: Once upon a time a great place; now stuck in the mollases

cons:
No roadmap and next to no guidance for employee careers
Compensation reviews as well as job grade flips are used as last resorts rather than rewarding employees for performance

headline: quite mean to engineer

cons: bad if you are engineer

headline: RF Engineer
pros: Lots of horizontal mobility, top end labs and equipment, very knowledgeable team
cons: Slow moving company, sales oriented, not research intensive.  The cubicles on south campus are a depressing environment to work in unless you are by a window.

headline: Great company
pros: Great company with a lot of opportunities. If you are ambitious you will get opportunities to contribute and participate in many different projects.
cons: I have not experienced any cons so far at Texas Instruments. Like every company, you need to work hard to keep up with everything that is happening.

headline: Great company hampered by conservatism and politics
pros: Great people, technology and brand recognition.
cons: Silo business units, incompetent management, engineers promoted into management roles they are incapable of doing.

headline: Company with lots of opportunity.
pros: Relationship company. Very aggressive and active work environment. Company has a very open door policy.

headline: interesting work but...

work with many different people from various sites.
some great people.
profit sharing
cons:
company strategy moving forward
trust in management

headline: Simple Review
pros: Great place to work with work/life balance.  I worked there for 8 1/2 years and loved what I did.  I learned a lot and gained additional education paid for by TI.  Take advantage of all the various resources available to employees.
cons: Very political and competitive environment.  Opportunities to move up were slim and unlikely.   It is all abut who you know and not your skill.

headline: quite okay
pros: best company to work with
cons: well TI is best to work with

A high intercultural environment at job. 
High flexibility in the workhours.
Good transference of knowledge from experienced employees to the new ones.
cons: Located in Freising. Although there's a good tranport conexion from Munich to Freising, it can take upto 1 hour to reach the facilities (if you area simple intern without auto). The best solution would be to live in Freiing.

headline: Its a good place to work
pros: Laid back, flexible schedule. It is a decent place to work.
cons: Heirarchial, things take very long. It can be frustrating if you are not in Dallas, but in a satellite site.

headline: Good work while you can keep it.
pros: Advanced Technical Engineering work, TI is very focused on customers and quality.  Lots of good people to work with.  As you would expect in a large company, there are some that are not so good.  TI will let you work as much as you want but they do expect long hours from salaried positions.  Good company and I would work for them again.
cons: Business is cyclical so lots of ups and downs.  Management also changes directions and has no problems with moving work off shore.  Don't expect to grow old at TI.

headline: Focusing on Analog now
pros:
-- Work life balance
-- Compensation
-- Work culture
cons: -- Focus going forward is shifting towards analog.

headline: Good place to work for young enginers
pros:
Geat talent to work with
good work life balance 
Great benefits
cons:
They hire alot and after few months huge layoffs follows
Job security is not guaranteed.

headline: working in TI for 5 years now
pros: good brand name and quality of work
cons: Business strategies not consistent and average pay

headline: The most caring "big organization" I have worked for.
pros: TI puts a lot of effort into making sure that employees feel valued and are taken care of...as much as any large, publicly held company can. As a contractor I felt little different than a direct hire. That is a rarity in any industry.
cons: Constant reorganizations make it difficult to establish efficient processes.

headline: A big company with aggressive business strategy
pros: Big company with a lot of opportunities; long history and you can learn a lot of product knowledge; good for starters
cons: Very aggressive on business goals; mid to high work loading; more working on short term goals

headline: Good company to work for - good work ethics and have many opportunities to make an impact
pros:
- Focused in analog - very strong engineers you can work with
- has an amazing sales force - great for sales and marketing roles
- flexible to allow lateral movement
- provides travel opportunities
- marketing is given importance
- situated in Texas, low cost of living
cons:
- Dallas could be boring for some
- very big company, hard to shine out
- progression may be slower than expected as you get higher up
- some work can get routine
- a lot of tight deadlines and firefighting can compromise work-life balance

headline: Technical Sales Representative
pros: Talented engineering, sales driven, and strong ethics.  Always feel challenged with a strong support infrastructure to help assist in securing customer commitments.  Huge portfolio and sales instrastructure WW.
cons: High stress and pressure environment for sales.  Recognizing achievement few and far between; breadth of product impressive, but differentiated in few areas.  Growing overhead of reporting taking away from investment at customers.

headline: Great Company....
pros: Good reputation, I always meet someone who had  mom or dad retire from here.  Good benefits
cons: Can become very political, so be prepared.

headline: Good company. Career ladder is possible at the "Right" location...
pros: The opportunity for career growth at TI and the benefit of continuing education tuition assistance is a plus. Also, being able to work only "1/2" a year because of "shift" work allows individuals to spend more time at home or go to school and get paid as a "full" time employee. With shift work you get 'paid" time and a half after 8hrs.
cons: Working at a  fab out of Dallas can limit your opportunity for growth due to limit of job openings.

headline: Great company to work for, need to develop creativity mindset.
pros: Open minded work style, Value Initiative, Trust and accountability, Can Do approach, Fast to react, Good working environment
cons: Not enough creativity oriented, Marketing/branding is weak

headline: Great Experience
pros: Diversity of the workforce and the diversity of assignments that you could work on were very broad.
cons: It tends to be very internally focused, not as open to outside ideas and inputs and might be beneficial.

headline: Good job to get trained for other opportunities
pros: This job was rewarding, challenging, and offered great benefits.
cons: The semicontuctor industry is cyclic and TI forces employees to take vacation or work without pay.

headline: Good company with excellent benifits.
pros:
Highly technical people
Good projects to work on
Good training
cons:
Too many layoffs
Some groups too plolitical.

headline: Nice environment to grow and learn
pros: large organization with ample opportunities to learn new skills and sharpen knowledge repository
cons: lack of focus on mobile and smartphone market.

headline: Big Company  with all the Pros and Cons
pros:
Access to cutting edge technology.
Ability to work with people from all around the world. 
Big budgets to go to major trade shows, advertise, do market research, etc.  
Good benefits, paternalistic culture to some extent.
cons:
Insular culture - if you're not from Texas, you're not really in, despite the many employees, including some senior managers, from around the world. 
Does not take internal criticism well. It was obvious the wireless business would lose to Intel and Qualcomm, but if you really questioned TI's strategy,  you were persona non grata.  No robust, internal self-critical culture. 
If you're not an engineer, you're a second class citizen.

headline: Beware of the field sales organization if you're over 30
pros: Great innovation, engineering and products, great support from factory, can-do spirit at factory.  good reputation in the marketplace with customers.  Good compensation.
cons: I joined the TI sales force in 2006, and it was a great place where they valued their people and developed them.  By 2011, that had turned 180 degrees and people were now a commodity and older, veteran people were unceremoniously made to feel unwelcome, so almost all of them left.  Regional sales manager positions with 20-30 reports were filled with people that 2 years before were college interns, a very nice slap in the face to the veteran people in the field who had been selling TI for years.  Also, TI stopped calling on "non-growth" customers, leaving them to the competition.  Management sought absolutely no feedback from the field.  This is a great place to work if you're a robot.

headline: Ok place to work  if you are a young graduate fresh from college
pros: Lots of product lines, at least used to...You can transfer to different department if your interest changes.
cons: The company lacks vision and long term commitment.

headline: Analog IC  layout designer
pros: I have had 2 Supervisors and both seem to be very understanding to personal/family needs as well as balancing both work and home.
cons: None to post at the moment

headline: Good learning and experience in semiconductors

cons: Career Growth is slow and limited.

headline: Worked for TI for 11 years.  Wish I hadn't moved on to a different company.
pros: Well established and well organized.  Effective at sharing resources between departments and teams to support projects of all sorts across multiple disciplines.
cons: Place heavy work loads on small teams.

headline: Company situation
pros:

Manage right balance between work and home

headline: QRA Engineering

headline: This is a company in a hurry

headline: TI was a great company to work for
pros:
Texas Instruments is still consider a good company
Some good people still left in the company
Dallas is one of the most affordable cities
cons:
Texas instruments is not the leading edge company that it used to be several years ago. 
Main business has become analogue with other areas being cut or closed.
SW is consider secondary and SW engineers are really not paid at the same level as SW eng. in SW companies.
TI much or less has re-orgs and layoffs every year (sometimes twice a year), more so since Rich Templeton became CEO (this is the only area he excels at)

My advice/survival guide for those SW eng. planning to join TI (assuming TI is your only option) is:
1. Become buddies with decision makers, this will come handy when layoffs come your way
2. Be political, don't rock the boa (specially if you are right) as you will be the first one in the layoff list
2. Don't kill yourself at work, due enough to get the job done and more importantly stand out as the problem solver even if you created the problem
4. Layoffs are inevitable, just be prepare and you will be OK if you master 1 and 2 above
5. Stay long enough to get good experience and then find a company where you can build a career (TI is not the place for SW eng.), advice is to stay 2-3 years then find something better

Dallas has very few high tech companies, hence it will be hard to find something else after layoffs.

I agree with others that TI facilities are "ghetto", where cubes are 20+ years and forget about free coffee or any other common perks available from companies making as much or less money than TI.

headline: The good and the bad
pros: TI has good ethics, good respect for the individual and is a leader in many of the fields it engages in. It has proven to be a survivor in the tech world (not so many other >75 year old tech companies). Good culture for helping others, people will generally go out of their way to help.
cons: High-level "strategy" is very sales-driven, and might not really be strategy in the true meaning of the word. Cuts can be brutal, when TI figures out that it wants to get out of a particular business, it does not hold back from cutting entire businesses. If you are in the wrong place at the wrong time, it doesn't really help how good you are. On the other hand, this is maybe a key reason why TI is still around (see >75 years on the pro side). Bureaucracy can feel stifling sometimes; support functions may be removed without reducing the paperwork load. Depending on the location, there may be a lot of politics at lower levels (Dallas is probably the worst location in this regard). At higher levels, there certainly appears to be some political wrangling - at least some decisions only make sense in this light. Although there is focus on work-life balance, workload can be on the high side. TI has succeeded in having some big windfalls with small staffing in some fields and may have too high expectations that this can be replicated across the board.

headline: Good place to work for with plenty of opportunities if you are young, enthusiastic, willing to learn
pros:
- Great learning and training atmosphere, get to learn from very experienced senior folks
- Opportunity to mentor and be mentored in turn
- Work and Health benefits are top notch and include rollover vacation
- Company does its best to minimize job losses
cons:
- Poor middle management quality, managers act like feudal lords and silo themselves instead of working across divisions, rarely get penalized for bad business decisions, many of them do not understand basics of competitive analysis, how to retain employees meaningfully, how to build a mature and contented team
- Recent years trending towards very short term focus instead of 3 - 5 year look ahead and encouraging innovation, technical ladder is a valuable asset with excellent people that is losing credibility as it has become a tool in the hands of managers to promote their favorites and retain squeaky employees
- Frequent organization changes are a distraction to committed employees, the problem with having sales and marketing managers in charge is they tend to think of design resources as interchangeable and skill sets as transferable, these changes prevent engineers from having a long term deep focus that results in fantastic innovation
- If one does not have management mentors and supporters, the workplace can appear stagnant for one's career; can become worse if one manages to speak one's mind and upsets middle management
- Management too focused on tasks and end goals and does not listen to the staff on the ground very much; constantly experimenting due to lack of experience in org leadership and personal insecurities

-Talented and experienced peers and seniors, hence ample knowledge available
cons:
-Big company. So, slow growth
-Work-life balance could be a juggling

headline: Better than average
pros: High ethic, good compensation, protection of employment
cons: bureaucracy, work and life balance, evaluation

headline: Depending on BU, can be fast paced exciting work or a slow crawl.
pros: Access to great training, both technical and leadership.  Great Engineering EDA support.
cons: bureacracy, politics, priorities inhibiting progress

headline: overall ok, nothing special to say
pros: options for re location, good salary
cons: bad bonus, stock is low

headline: The best experience I've ever had
pros:
Great people to work with
Technology leaders
Great ideas
Expand you knowledge while developing the newest technologies in the market, and be the first to deal with such technologies
cons: I can't remember that I faced or noticed any cons

headline: more political and negative than it used to be
pros: stable company, not going out of business, mostly good people
cons: political, "stick" culture (versus "carrot"), constant reorganizations

headline: One company, with dozens of companies within.
pros: Great A type personalities to work with. You will learn a lot in this high paced environment. If you work in a big location like dallas, the campus is very nice.
cons: Too much change in organizations, and some business groups are growing while others are drowning. They have no issues with laying off entire teams from business groups that are not preforming well. They only way you can survive at TI is to smell trouble early on and jump from group to group before layoff comes. Its sad, but the simple truth.

headline: Overall a good company to work for where you can achive life work balance
pros: Depending on which business unit you work for, stress level can vary, but overall it's an easy work place. Company value and culture is very solid, people are generally well treated.
cons: Compensation is not outstanding. As a big old company, it had to go through frequent reorgs to adapt to various challenges. Not every reorg was smart move. Employees may feel frustrated with the inefficiencies and overhead of a large organization.

headline: Technical Marketing Engineer
pros: Great people and good place to work
cons: People are not ambitious to get promoted or get business.

headline: Challenging, but not always for the right reasons...
pros: Plenty of good here.  Competitive salary, great benefits, lots of different potential roles.  Exciting to drive the next generation of hardware.
cons: Middle management quagmire, good decisions often blocked by political interplay.  Many of the development models are antiquated and highly inefficient, but almost impossible to modify.

headline: Great company
pros: Stable and ethical and now with a large presence in the Bay Area.  They have formalized processes and you typically know where you stand within the organization.
cons: Sometimes slow to move as they often operate like a large company.  Most employees are in Texas which can limit career opportunities for those not wiling to move back there.  A heavy focus on analog.

headline: Summer Intern in TI
pros: I have been working with two different teams in different branches in IT. They all have very relax working atmosphere and you have flexible working hours. I worked from home several times during my summers.
cons: I really do not have any complain about their summer intern programming.  The only thing I don't like is that the summer in Dallas is simply too hot.

headline: Not bad, not great
pros: Good healthcare and benefits.  Great portfolio.  All the resources you could want.
cons: Slow to market due to fear of failure and size of company.  Always playing catch-up.  Little innovation.

headline: Good company to settle down.
pros: Employee friendly, give every option to balance b/w job & life.
cons: Cool employee life which moves to poor management for market competition

headline: Good company to settle down.
pros: Employee friendly, give every option to balance b/w job & life.
cons: Cool employee life which moves to poor management for market competition

headline: Great Company, fast paced, dynamic and always striving to stay at the forefront
pros: Challenging fast paced enviroment. Very competative salary, flexable work hours. Longevity. Very diverse work enviroment.
cons: Very demanding, long hours, nights and weekends as necessary.

headline: Exciting, Challenging, Demanding....that's it
pros: Benefits are well taken care of, visionary and always look ahead.
cons: Stressful environment, although I take it as a challenge.

headline: It started out as a company that cared about people and ended up as a company that only cared about profit.
pros: Good Benefits, Average Pay, many good smart people to work with. It is a US company.
cons: Poor Management that does not know or understand their products, customers or employees. Made every one feel like a number.

headline: Excellent company to work for
pros: Great people to work with some of the best Layout designers in the world
cons: not much wrong with this company

headline: good place to learn basics
pros: good place to learn basics, high ethical standards, less politics, very bright minds at work, flexi timing, no nonsense of being inside office for stipulated amount of time
cons: growth oppurtunity is very less, always less than average salary as compared to the other IC design companies, a company which does not grow aggressively and does not take any risks on any vector

headline: Test Engineer
pros: Great benefits for full time employees.
cons: Culture with in department working was not conducive to productive work.

headline: Great international support
pros: There is great international support to local operations from the head quarters. The team is formed by capable ans specialist professionals, which promotes a good international synergy.  There is a good environment to work; possibility to travel and learning rotations in other countries.
cons: There is a limited head count in some locations, which limits the number of employees per office depending on a series of factors. Therefore some employees are hired through third parties.

headline: SW Engineer (Israel,Raanana). Connectivity division
pros:
Conservative, stable, good compensation, excellent people. Invest in workers. Food 3 times a day.
Location is pretty convenient. Technological challenge. Finally one of the best places i ever worked for.
cons:
Not dynamic enough. Force organized vacations. 
Follows after market leaders. If decides the niche is big enough for another player, enters the market. Barely competes against aggressive market players. Connectivity division has lost direction and tries to reinvent itself.

headline: good challenging analog design opportunities
pros: very good level of products diversity
cons: work force spread across, world wide

headline: Fantastic working culture, environment and salary levels, although too showy.
pros:
Salary level above par the industry
Working culture is excellent
Highly regarded professionals
Conducive learning atmosphere
cons:
Things change too constantly and randomly.
Politics play a major role in promotions
Strategies are too conflicting
Confused state of direction

headline: Good for Analog
pros: Very good learning environment and ok salary
cons: some teams are good some are bad

headline: Senior Software Engineer
pros: Working on some interesting problem and the schedule is not crazy,
cons: It's too laid back, and people stay 20-30 years there, not much opportunity for the new comer

headline: Great Work Environment. Great People. Good Salary.
pros:
Awesome People around you.
Work Ethics.
Good Salary.
cons: Quality of Work. Limited cross domain opportunities.

headline: TI is results-driven, competitive and full of opportunity.
pros: TI is so large, there are many opportunities for variety and growth.
cons: There are the typical issues you would expect with a large company.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Benifits are better than most companies out there.
cons: Semiconductor Manufacturing operations run 24/7

headline: Technical Sales Engineer
pros: Sales environment, touch many products and active areas for growth
cons: Strict adherence to short term goals over long term can be discouraging at times

headline: Future for OMAP business is unclear, expecting company to cut down heavily on new investments
pros:
Strong analog portfolio
Many opportunities to move internally to different business units
Competitive salary
(at least so far) very supportive customer base
cons:
Immature management (middle level)
On OMAP side, unclear vision from company leadership
Bleak outlook for embedded processing in general
Losing the customer base

headline: Test Engineer review
pros: Diverse Company, Lots of opportunity to succeed
cons: spend lots of long hours at work

headline: Good company to work for but not doing financially as great as other competitors
pros: Great benefits and relocation packages, good people overall, you will always find someone who can help you. 401k matching and Good culture & values for the employee.
cons:
It's not doing as great as other competitors.
Depending where you are working, you don't always get enough time to be trained.
Lots of pressure from customers, be ready to work on the weekends

headline: Top compensation, heavy load
pros: Excellent compensation scheme, you will find rather wide variety of technologies involved in the design, opportunity to work at one of the wold largest chip makers, chance for relocation if you care about this, you can land long term freelance job there.
cons: Forget about home - lab and your cube is all you are going to see. Naturally it depends on specific project, but in most cases you are going to work hard and be pushed even harder.

headline: for the most part pretty ok
pros:
good benefits
established protocols
plenty of experienced people to help you in any area
cons:
sometimes politics
not easy to be visible since big company

headline: all my efforts were paid
pros: The company pays higher than what is mandated by the government
cons: nothing I can think of

headline: Really great company to work for
pros: Transparent Culture, great cutting edge technology, clients from all verticals
cons: Clarity in terms of business decisions impacting employees

headline: Amazing
pros:
Good package
Friendly environment
Very supportive seniors,mentors & supervisors
Great learning
Flexible working hours/Work from home without any issues
cons:
Should be less politics
Should be focused on HVLs based testing

headline: Long time employee disillusioned by culture of finger pointing advancing frat-boy types
pros: Depending on your job type you can do your work well and rewarded.
cons:
If you are in a management or strategic position, the politics are counter productive.
The buzz word accountability has become to mean that "stuff" rolls down hill.
Very few people at the GM level or above will openly take responsibility.

headline: Well structured intern experience
pros:
- Easy to ask questions of anyone within the organization at all levels 
- Respect intern opinions 
- Challenging, real assignments as opposed to grunt work
cons:
- Can sometimes be stuck in the old way of doing things and resistant to change 
- Can be difficult to get up to speed with how quickly things change
- Not a lot of central knowledge sharing - can contribute to reinventing the wheel in a lot of ways

headline: Great company to work for.
pros:
Well managed company, good colleagues ww, thorough quarterly feedback from management,
fine bonus agreements.
cons: Be sure to balance work/life yourself

headline: This is a company that cares about employee but business decision was executed slower than ideal
pros: cares about employee, very good reputation among the industry, good training experience offered.
cons: very tough to move up, slower decision execution than ideal, staff getting older

headline: Fun job, very team specific
pros: Knowledgeable team, get to work on a huge variety of projects and technologies, you can have the opportunity to architect complete hardware solutions.
cons: You are a part of the sales organization. Great for pay, but you deal with sales team a lot... Hours can be very long (80+ hrs/week for 4-6 month stretches)

headline: Program Director
pros: Large scale global projects, excellent experience
cons: Work around the clock..there's always someone somewhere in the world actively working on your programs.

headline: The new maintenance mechanic program is a joke.
pros: The schedule and tuition program.
cons: Politics, no advancement in current program.

headline: Struggling hard to find its place, after wireless sale
pros: Great tech people, has good technology access. Was number 1 in wireless, had great application processor business and MCU business, now everything looks to be in disarray
cons: Poor managers and leaders, lacks vision. Change of strategic direction is not looking promising. Appears to be selecting strategy based on ease of  implementation and not on sound reasoning.

headline: Senior sales account manager for analog and embedded processors
pros: Good internal information infrastructure to get things like
cons: Numerous paper work and sales reviews waste too much time

headline: Object Engineer
pros: If you want to just come to work and do a job until you retire this is the place for you.  Software development is secondary to any Engineering or Manufacturing so innovation turns really slowly in the Applications/Automations develop areas.   If your halfway good this is a really easy gig that you can probably do in 8 hours a week of work and surf the net for the rest of the week (sans meetings).
cons: Work with proprietary frameworks that no one ont the planet other than TI employees have heard of.   Coding standards are non-existent.  No one has heard the terms of Technical Debt, factory pattern, or IOC.   Low pay compared to market.  Much of the commodity IT is being moved over seas so you need to stay up nights talking with them on the phone since they can't work during our hours.

headline: Good experience
pros: Good opportunities to those who do good work.
cons: Business is cyclical.  Decisions are sometimes short sighted.

headline: Been a great place to work, but may be time to move on when economy improves.
pros: Have had opportunities to work in many different groups, with great opportunities to expand my base of knowledge in areas like Engineering, Marketing, Operations, and Finance
cons: Your supervisor is typically not actively trying to promote you as much as themselves. You definitely have to have a strong network in order to continue to move into more challenging and exciting roles.

headline: company with excellent work culture and Very high potential for growth
pros: good work culture, flat organization, equal opportunity for growth, competitive salary, intellect people...lot more
cons: HR department need to think about there policies, facilities like food (its nearly non eatable), refresh area's, games etc are not good....

headline: Great but too much work
pros: Lots of career opportunities. Lots of interesting people and interesting projects
cons: Too much money oriented. Hectic management.

headline: Great company but new hire training needs work
pros: Casual atmosphere. Great resume builder.
cons: Training for new hires is not sufficient. Sink or swim type of environment depending on group you're in. You don't want to be a fab engineer.

headline: Company with high potential/upside for growth
pros: Fast moving, highly competitive, good quality products
cons: High turn over rate, less training on personal development to employees

headline: Interesting and sometimes challenging
pros:
Large, well managed company from a financial perspective.
Several diverse groups with an opportunity to find one that fits you.
cons: Too many managers with too narrow of a focus.  They look out for their own priorities without regard for corporate priorities.

headline: Below average career growth opportunities; big organization to steer through
pros: Open door policy which is good for learning. Good compensation compared to others in the area. Lots of opportunity to learn and contribute. Moderate to high work pressure however it is not hard to have a work-life balance here.
cons: Lacks environment to support growth for personnel and partiality and politics is prevalent. Lacks fair growth programs and management participation is low in them. Marred by age old mentality as being an old company and upper level management is resistant to change. Division among various engineering roles lead to friction in team mostly due to lack of respect for other roles. While it seems that being a large company gives more avenues to grow however it is hard to find and materialize a fresh chance. Operating efficiency is on the lower side.

headline: So long & thanks for 10 years experience. I really learned a lot.
pros: The best is the access to some of the industries top engineers in an environment where knowledge sharing is encouraged. You can really learn your craft here. And you might even become tops in your field here, if you learn how to rise in the system.
cons: Too easy to get lost in the crowd. Creating good products and meeting extreme schedules is not enough. Being the "go to guy" for applications and test engineers is not enough either. Frankly, I'm not sure what is enough. Maybe I just didn't create enough drama while getting my job done.

headline: overall a good large company to work for
pros: Overall A good place to work for, it is difficult but you can try moving between different functions . Overall a good large scale company
cons: but if you are looking for fast career growth opportunties the probably not the right place .. off late doing many reorg changes..

headline: Good place for fresh grads.
pros: good learning environment, traveling chances and career expansion
cons: steep learning curve & demanding at times

headline: It's great in TI.
pros: Good benifits, good career, good working atmosphere, great manager and leader.
cons: Not enough salary. Some bosses are not good enough to lead.

headline: It's Fun and you will enjoy your job
pros: They have their missions and visions
cons: Low compensation and benefits to the employee

headline: Cool place to work lot to learn and enjoy at the same time
pros: Good guidance good growth good challanges
cons: Pay less than market standards

headline: I work as Analog layout engineer in texas instruments
pros: You will get to work on challenging problems
cons: Work pressure is too high

headline: Variety of engineering challenges
pros: Opportunity to work in different groups over the years.  Good variety of product markets learned.  Ability to move between hardware, software and system engineering jobs.  Profit sharing bonus has been good for a number of years.
cons: More focused concentration on chip level market exploration, less large system prototyping to explore markets.  Less team work, more individual result rewarded.  Very top performers are highly compensated, with minimal compensation for everyone else.

headline: Good place for engineers.
pros:
- Lots of autonomy.
- Generally strong management team.
- Established, stable company.
cons: - Sometimes difficult to drive innovation and change.

headline: Great Engineering Company, but not much individual growth prospects
pros:
Great place for engineering innovation 
Good place if you want to stay at one place ,possibly till your retirement
cons: Not much for individual's growth, especially for young engineers as there are lot of long timers and would recommend if you are trying to go into management path

headline: for people who love to work at semicon
pros: good stepping stone to work abroad
cons: not good management due to poor communication

headline: Place to settle down
pros:
- Easy going culture
- Generally flexible work-life balance (lots depend on your manager)
- Well paid
- Opportunity to grow technically and in managerial stream
cons:
- Very slow growth 
- Slow decision making process
- Lack of aggression or ownership for decision leading to the above

headline: Great place to work..
pros:
> Great work culture - People are easy to deal with, people respect you for you capabilities and the value you bring to the table
> You work on the cutting edge of technology - TI is among the best companies an Electronics grad can work in
> Ample opportunities for making an impact
> One of the highest pay packages for undergrads/freshers within the Electronics industry
cons:
> If you get into TI, you would most probably be among the best of your lot. For a person of your caliber (particular if you are a fresher or have a degree in computer science), there are opportunities in other firms like Google, Microsoft, Amazon etc that might be available and can pay better. 
Simply put, although TI offers some of the best jobs (pay wise, work quality wise, growth wise) in the Electronics industry, firms in the Software industry offer a more rewarding career.

headline: Wonderfully Bright People
pros: A lot of very bright people work at TI and they are very flexible with time.
cons: Recent closings of sites. Fewer internal symposia/events than in years past.

headline: Good pay and benefits, but getting off nights is difficult.
pros: It is a well-paying job for an hourly position.  Most fellow employees are good to work with.  The benefits are good in comparison to other companies.
cons: It can be very hard to get off of nights.  Revolving door managers are disconnected to staff because they don't expect to be in the position more than two years.

headline: Good company to work for
pros:
Flexibility in working on things you feel are important.
management is generally supportive.
cons: Not a lot of time for personal life

headline: TI- good company to start your career
pros:
- newest technology
- good company for  graduated
- friendly enviroment
cons:
- be careful if you decide to work with this company throught vendor (3rd party employment)
- you need to wait for promotion quite long

headline: TI- good company to start your career
pros:
- newest technology
- good company for  graduated
- friendly enviroment
cons:
- be careful if you decide to work with this company throught vendor (3rd party employment)
- you need to wait for promotion quite long

headline: Applications Engineer
pros: very good learning opportunity, good work life balance
cons: slow growth verticaly, sometimes feels lke mundane work.

headline: Too much politics & favoritism.
pros: Low cost of living; OK benefits package.
cons: Frequent re-orgs, new groups get created every few months and older ones get merged without any sound resons. Promotions are rarely based on merit - it depends largely on how much ass-kissing you can do, and to some extent, on your gender. Many bright engineers have left in the last 3-4 years; many more want to leave, but are stuck due to family or other personal reasons. Morale is low.

headline: Great Technology, informal work environment, Great to start career with.
pros:
- Technical Learning is immense
- Switching your domains is possible and is very well supported
- Is the best company to start your career with due to the learning
- Technical risk taking is encouraged and supported
cons:
- No performance appraisal system, the evolving system is employee infriendly and opaque. Your performance is at the discretion of higher ups and you will just get to end results (Good/bad)
- No formal mentoring system. It exists on paper but is discouraged
- Fairness is not the central idea of performance appraisal.

headline: overall feeling
pros: big company, good reputation and many experienced and nice people
cons: work load is light compared to some other companies. Not very good for people who wants work harder and learn quickly

headline: An electronics company pushing the envelope of success
pros: An exposure to excellent work ethics
cons: Balance between work and life maybe hard to maintain

headline: Good place to settle down
pros:
Low cost of living in TX
Sound long term management strategy
Good and ethical financials
cons:
Closed "inner circle" of upper management
Promotions not always based on merit
Unfair "affirmative action" promoting unfit women managers to leadership roles (some are actually good, but most do not get any respect)

headline: Good company to work for...but too many changes
pros: Good mentors, flexible work schedule. Latest technology.
cons: Too much changes off late and focus shifts. Becoming Analog centric

headline: Good experience overall
pros: Good pay for a co-op, certainly a good learning experience and addition to your resume, location is not bad
cons: Management is not very genuine, you never know what they are thinking about you. Do not trust the compliments they keep giving you about your work. If they do not like you personally, it does not matter how good of a job you do. They like too much A** kissing. In cases you have to wok a lot more hours than you normally do.

headline: My experience at Ti was awesome. And I had an opportunity to learn a lot from a bunch of very talented individuals
pros: Exposure, Work culture, opportunity, Salary, flexible work hours, employee benefits, excellent  team, extensive lab facility and very helpful colleagues
cons: At times no time for personal life

headline: Big MNC company with structured system and work process
pros:
Good working environment and culture
Good learning
cons: Pay is below market rate

headline: good
pros: good work life balance and career opportunities
cons: semiconductor industry face challenge, so salary is not competitive

headline: A good company to work at
pros: TI IL is a place where you can growth your carrier in high end technolagy and worm and family environment.
cons: like every site that is not the head quoters, TI IL has a limitted roles and at some stage of your carrieer you are getting stack in position. moving to higher position is limited in IL and mosdt of the time required re-location to Dallas.

headline: This is really a great company to work.
pros: We will get opportunity to work with good techies
cons: Work pressure and assessing our work in every aspect.

headline: happy for 12 years
pros:
I was with TI India for 7+ years and was given opportunity to relocate to US site.

good culture, flexible work hours, open to work with different business groups, have typical extra benefits like medical/dental/vision insurance perks, 401k, ESPP, etc.
cons: career growth gets limited in big organizations, average compensation particularly when you get relocated from non-US location

headline: TI Review
pros: Great environment to work, under right manager great chance to flourish
cons: constant change in management so focus changes time and again

headline: 4 out of 5
pros:
- Leader in Analog
- Good Compensation
- time flexibility
cons: - Do not have all the amenities on-campus

headline: Excellent
pros: It is excellent place to excel in your area of strenght
cons: U need to be master of many trades to excel which is not easy

headline: Good place to gain experience on mobile technologies but very little career growth beyond individual contributions
pros:
- Located in Texas where housing is cheap and no state income taxes makes an average salary go a long way
- Good benefits
- Family friendly atmosphere, everyone leaves at 5.30!
cons:
- No career growth if you are an engineer
- Very little scope to switch careers, get slotted in a role and continue forever
- No urgency to innovate

headline: Good place to work for
pros:
Very open environment to share new ideas - lots of great minds around
Lots of people with > 15yrs experience : easy to find mentors :
A "TI" Culture has evolved over years - where mutual respect is easy to find
Leading edge work - no dearth of opportunities
cons:
Frequent long working hours - work-life balance is not as good as it used to be couple of years back
Pay is not the best in class - though good work always get appreciated.
experienced recruit (specially managers) don't fit into the culture and often below "TI" standards

headline: Good place to work for. Nice work environment. Salary up to the industry standard
pros:
Very good work environment
Excellent recreational facilities
Salary matching the semiconductor industry
Talented and hard working employees are rewarded accordingly. Company believes differential growth driven by commitment of the employee.
cons: Relatively high work volume. Not the highest paying company but this is compensated by a better work environment

headline: Great opps for growth
pros: Good opportunities or growth even for young people, good salary, reasonable work like balance
cons: Lack of great people to learn fom

headline: Excellent and ethical
pros: Ethical and focussed in its domain
cons: conservative and risk averse at large

headline: Texas Instruments is a stable company
pros: Large company, several groups doing different things.
cons: Growth potential is very minimal

headline: Good company to learn international activities
pros: Good and dynamic, stable and strong
cons: Too many business to understand globally what the company is doing

headline: Different Experience
pros: You will gain experience soon.
cons: Doesn't suit people with no interest or prior knowledge in this field

headline: Was a GREAT company to work for as an engineer, but increasingly badly run
pros: Lots of resources, varied work opportunities
cons: Over the last five years, management has moved in a very bad direction. Too much management change, inability to set a plan and stick with it long enough to get positive results. Micromanagement rife at every level, too many completely non-technical people in charge of technical people, bad news unacceptable. Evidence of "shoot the messenger" behavior. People are holding off from reporting bad news for fear of consequences. Increasing perception that upper management does not understand the value in experience. This is not healthy.

headline: Good work/life balence at the cost of a slow/no moving environment
pros: Good benefits, professional development and growth opportunities and family friendly. Vacation and PTO particularly generous. Good place to start a career as there's mentoring. Good place to end/plateau a career as you can maintain efforts and still add value.
cons: Not close to cutting edge. Average performance seems to be tolerated. Empty suits are obvious but still remain, which doesn't do much for morale. Can be frustrating if you want to run -- company can walk quickly, but can't/won't run. Silos have been built over the years in businesses and corporate.

headline: Besure of getting learning and growing opportunities yourself
pros: some very knowledgeble collegue, good enviroment, nice people. good benefit pakage, vacation pakage, health insurance plan, workout facility, family event, community involvement.
cons: Management should consider giving more growing opportunities to employees and consider their learning and growing need than just specify schedule.

headline: Technically challenging, creatively satisfying (push for innovation) , a very open and flexible environment
pros:
1. Very open environment, knowledgeable and helpful team-mates.
2. Employees are valued a lot and are given immense freedom.
3. Opportunity to work on cutting-edge in semiconductor industry
cons:
1. Not a very aggressive company. 
2. A little ambiguity in business strategy.
3. Slightly lower compensation than the highest in the industry.

headline: The work environment is great! Work and responsibilities are also fine
pros: Brand Name, Work environment. One may get to work in leading edge technology.
cons: Decent salary, can be more. Growth opportunities are ok

headline: Very talented engineers and managment.
pros: Cutting edge technology and innovation
cons: Turned from a personal realtionship type working relationship where your word counted to a CA attitude... "its just business"

headline: ok
pros: the environment of working is comfort
cons: everybody keep chasing your team where there are a team just lay on their chair doing nothing but having same monthly income with you.

headline: Attrition is high
pros: Good benefits, medical, dental and vision
cons: Be prepared to have a marketing manager

headline: Awesome
pros: Best possible compensation. Great engagement with the team and mentoring. Excellent work-life balance. Highly intellectual team mates to interact with.
cons: Insulated team culture. Suffers from lack of greater visibility for an invdividual of large corporate.

headline: Good
pros: It's a big company, very steady.
cons: Work with different time zone

headline: Great!
pros:
-Challenging roles
-Good support networks
-Family environment
-Good training
cons:
-Complex procedures
-No clear career path progression

pros: I like the fact that I had 3 days off one week and 4 days the next week. The pay is competitive. It wasn't a bad place to work if you can deal with a 12 hour shift.
cons: No room for career or professional advancement. You will be a Manufacturing Specialist for 20+ years.

headline: Getting to learn a lot
pros: Work culture is very good and obviously the salary is very nice .Work -life balance is fine and its very light working environment
cons: You may have to wait for long hours when product release is nearby, but that happens almost in every firm in this industry

headline: An amazing work-life balance.
pros: A lot of facilities given early in the job, work-life balance with Texins (Texas Sports Club), Ample opportunitites
cons: A very long technical and management ladder to climb, Less recognition due to huge number of employees

headline: An amazing work-life balance.
pros: A lot of facilities given early in the job, work-life balance with Texins (Texas Sports Club), Ample opportunitites
cons: A very long technical and management ladder to climb, Less recognition due to huge number of employees

headline: Good Technical Growth
pros:
1. Good Technical Growth
2. Cooperation amongst employees
3. Less red tape and hence agile
4. Encouragement for innovation
5. Good Cash Reserve
cons:
1. Poor Employee Recognition
2. Not an objective decision making management
3. Not growing in size - stagnant
4. Short sighted vision of management - Poor strategic planning
5. Very little freebies and goodies/ incentive for employee retention

headline: Texas Instruments Is a Good Company to work for.
pros: Technology is advanced, with many diversified product portfolio. Each organization has unique structure of business(manufacturing structure, Wireless Business, DLP,  DSP,  and HPA). Most groups are easy to work with. The benefits and pay are great.  Most engineers share their knowledge.
cons:
There are a few bad groups and managers(just like any company). H1 Visas and college hires is a big strategy for hiring.  For many years, TI was called Training Institute(hiring college graduates). They are back in that mode during the recession. Three years ago, there were 30 percent H1 visas. Now it is 60 percent walking down the corridor.  They are on the edge of segregation per language barrier, but hey  still have a chance to prevent this problem. 

    You have to watch how their technology is not standardized with other companies. They build many systems internal and unique. Not good during a downturn.

headline: It's a place where you can learn everyday and gain real experience rather than repeating the same things again and again
pros:
1. Great Management Culture.
2. Excellent set of people that work with you. The threshold of competence is very high, so it is easy to work.
3. Very inclusive environment with all kinds of diversity.
cons: Not anything serious that I can think of. Dallas summers can be quite hot. Learning curve might be steep at time due to the complexity of systems.

headline: Number one semiconductor manufacturer!
pros:
Very diversified portfolio, which means many different opportunities exist.
Flat hierarchy. Very good for new employees.
No state income tax as based in Texas.
cons: A little bit conservative in jumping in new markets.

headline: Interesting, I learned a lot
pros:
Strong IP portfolio, 
relatively easy to move to different business unit if you are good
good benefits, offer a lot of training
cons: sometimes slow towards new technology

headline: Great company to work
pros:
-Flexible work schedule
-Lots of opportunity to grow, try new things
-Good recognition
-Company really cares about employees
cons: -Lacks a global recognition program

headline: You work here and we own you
pros: Company has tremendous  financial resources and massive product portfolio offering.  Employee benefits (health, vision, 401k, ESSP) are very competitive with other like companies.
cons: No work life balance.  Not a good place to work if you have a family or want to ever have the opportunity to spend time with them

headline: Very old company
pros:
Well organized
Fair compensation
Good knowledge sharing
cons:
A way too old company with unbelievable regulations everywhere
Restriced working environment, lake of flexibility in every aspect, lake of efficiency
Not performance driven, talent not rewarded
Stopped in new technology development recently

headline: Work was boring, but they love co-ops at TI
pros: TI is very supportive of co-ops and new hires.  Every single recent grad in their rotational program had great things to say about their experiences, and most of my fellow co-ops really enjoyed their work and their supervisors.  The facilities in Dallas were really nice.  TI definitely has their stuff together and seems to have a knack for getting into the right markets.
cons:
During the summer I spent at TI, my team was in the middle of a very uninteresting phase of work.  Applications teams get to do a lot of cool, hands-on stuff, but while I was there, they were preparing documentation, tweaking software tools, generating header files, etc.--extremely tedious, logistical tasks that could almost be done by a team of fairly knowledgeable high school students.  Apparently I was just unlucky, because I met about 100 other co-ops who were doing interesting stuff.  
Seems like a bad move to put co-ops or new grads on teams that are doing mind-numbing work... the real value of a co-op is not their work, but their potential as a future employee.  Even though I got a chance to see that TI is a cool place, my experience left a bad taste in my mouth.

headline: great place to work
pros: good compensation, good location, good career development.
cons: tight communication and collaboration between different group needs to improve.

headline: Pleasurable
pros: Good Co Workers and Pay
cons: Management needs to listen to all employees.

headline: Technically competent company but too rigid in outlook
pros:
Very technically competent people
Stable company
Forefront of technology
cons:
Very little empowerment of employees
Company resistant to change
Arrogant business attitude
A lot of wasted effort on projects that get canned

headline: Very good work place with smart and technically competent people
pros: Diversity, benefits and the opportunities within TI
cons: slow job growth like any large corporation

headline: TI used to be a great place to work, but not any more
pros: Flexible hours. Decent pay and benefits.
cons: Non-stop reorg and lay-off recently. People just don't feel stable and secure working for TI these days. Virtually no opportunity for engineers to advance their careers. TI has essentially stopped investing in its digital side business especially DSPs, which it used to dominate even 5-6 years ago. All upper and middle management are now coming from the sales side and has no clue nor interest in technology. All the emphasis is on sales and marketing. In the past several quarters, TI spend more money buying back its own stocks than investing in R&D. This speaks loudly about what TI is really about these days.TI's internal cost control is to such extreme that it has become even laughable in certain aspects. For example, replacing 4-5 year old PCs has been really difficult if not impossible. This results in big loss of productivity in return for a few hundred dollars of savings.

headline: Very good company, great benefits, but conservative with raises.
pros: Generally a very good work life balance.  They have great insurance benefits and great vacation times.  Managers are all pretty fair.
cons: They are very conservative with raises, even for the top performers.  You need to work in Dallas in order to really advance your career.

headline: Ok
pros: Stability, perks, profit sharing, insurance, etc.
cons: Cost cutting, lack of care for older employees, etc.

headline: Work like a tool without much recognition
pros: Company participate in van pool program
cons:
Focus on marketing rather technology
Company has too few restrooms, not enough washing facility either

headline: good place to "work"

affordable place to live (Dallas area)

pros: you are not told exactly what to do, but you have to perform well and it is okay to find new ways to your goals.

pros: Very flexible hours, relaxed atmosphere, ability to work at own pace, profit sharing, employee stock purchase plan, great 401k and insurance benefits

headline: Just a place to learn and come out

headline: Disappointed by upper managements lack of vision and leadership
pros: Nice work environment.  Calm, comfortable place to work.  Beautiful site.
cons:
Very poor re-partition of tasks between TI's sites when there was no justification in terms of different skills at the various sites.  We were effectively in competition with our colleagues in India/Dallas while we were supposed to be collaborating with them.

As a big multinational, it's very difficult to effect any change at TI and of course inter-site politics hamper getting things done effectively.

headline: Great place to work, learn, and meet the best of the best.
pros: The openness of experienced members in and across departments and groups is phenomenal - anyone is willing to help out a colleague.
cons: Feedback from upper level management can be hard to spot at times. Restructuring of management is a great improvement to create a better symbiotic relationship.

headline: Worked at worst places-Plenty to do and learn here. Don't expect loyalty to get you very far-it's all about the numbers.
pros: Diversity of people is vast. Global scope of the enterprise is awesome.
cons: Too big and abstract at times. Politics are done better and more artfully than any other place I have worked.

headline: High level of micro-management.   A lot of turn over from high level intelligent engineers due to lack of empowerment
pros:
Good Salary
Lower level management is good
Stable
cons:
Very bad work life balance.  

Management not invested in providing enough resources only bottom line

Higher level management micro manages and is out of touch.

Higher level management will change technical ranking made by lower management based on "their" favorites whether they are good performers or not.

headline: An excellent company for career opportunities, professionnal satisfaction and work-life balance

cons:

pros: Freedom to do your work and not excessive management interference.  Management team at the local level and next level are focused on the real challenges that impact your work.
